{{Short description|Painting by Edward Hopper}} {{Italic title}} {{Infobox artwork/wikidata | image = Hotel Lobby by Edward Hopper.JPG }} '''''Hotel Lobby''''' is an [[oil painting]] on [[canvas]] by American [[Realist visual arts|realist]] painter [[Edward Hopper]]; it is held in the collection of the [[Indianapolis Museum of Art]] (IMA), in [[Indianapolis, Indiana]], United States.<ref name="HotelLobby">{{cite web | author= | year=2010 | title=Hotel Lobby | work=Collections | publisher =[[Indianapolis Museum of Art]] | url=http://www.imamuseum.org/art/collections/artwork/hotel-lobby-hopper-edward | accessdate = 14 April 2010}}</ref>
==Description==
The painting depicts two women and a man in the lobby of a hotel. On the right is a woman with blond hair and a blue dress, sitting with her legs crossed and reading a book. To the left sits an older woman with a red dress, a coat and a hat. A man stands next to her, facing forward, with a suit on and an overcoat draped over his right arm. On the left wall, above the woman, is a framed landscape painting. A clerk behind the reception desk is barely visible in the shadows.<ref name="HotelLobby"/>
==Context==
''Hotel Lobby'' is a signature piece in Hopper's work, displaying his classic themes of [[wiktionary:alienation|alienation]] and [[wiktionary:brevity|brevity]].<ref name="HotelLobby"/> The Hoppers traveled frequently, staying in many motels and hotels throughout his career. This is one of two works in his catalog that depicts a hotel, the other being ''Hotel Window'' (1955). The older couple are believed to represent Hopper and his wife, at that date in their 60s.<ref name="Warkel">{{cite book |last=Warkel |first=Harriet G. |coauthors= |title=Paper to Paint: Edward Hopper's ''Hotel Lobby'' |publisher=[[Indianapolis Museum of Art]] |year=2009 |month= |isbn=978-0-936260-84-6}}</ref> The hotel guests have been described as being "both traveling and suspended in time,"<ref name="HotelLobby"/> reflecting a stoic and dramatic feeling, reminiscent of the [[film noir]] movies Hopper might have seen and the complex structure and feeling of works by [[Edgar Degas]]. <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Hotel Lobby by Edward Hopper Detail 2.JPG| thumb| Light detail]] --> The painting utilizes harsh light and rigid lines to create a "carefully constructed" uncomfortable environment. The elevated and [[theatrical]] [[wikt:vantage point|vantage point]] of the painting may be derived from Hopper's love of [[Broadway theatre]] which he often watched from the balcony.<ref name="HotelLobby"/>
===Sketches===
Before he created the ''Hotel Lobby'' Hopper drew ten studies of the work, which are in the collection of the [[Whitney Museum of American Art]], as a gift for his wife, Josephine.<ref name="Warkel"/><ref name="ArtistPanel">{{cite journal |last1=Meyerowitz |first1=Joel |last2=Segal |first2=George |last3=Bailey |first3=William |last4=Levin |first4=Gail |year=1981 |title=Artists' Panel |journal=[[Art Journal (CAA)|Art Journal]] |volume=41 |issue=2 |pages=151–153 |publisher=[[College Art Association]] |doi= |jstor=776464 }}</ref><ref name="IndianapolisMonth1">{{cite journal |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |year=2008 |title=Indianapolis Museum of Art |journal=[[Indianapolis Monthly]] |volume= |issue=September |pages=170 |publisher=[[Emmis Communications]] |doi= }}</ref> Nine of the ten studies are described as:
*Study one was believed to have been executed while Hopper in a hotel lobby observed two seated figures separated by a lamp and table. That wall features a curtained opening, a registration desk and a painting on the wall with the stairwell and railing on the left. *Study two lacks the table and lamp and includes a second painting, which is separated from the other by a wall sconce, and one figure. *Study three depicts the stairwell being moved into the background. A figure believed to be male stands in the open doorway to the left of the stairs while a woman sits to the left of the doorway with an empty chair, a painting on the wall and a tiled floor. *Study four is more refined and has greater detail. The stairs are now removed with three people on the left: two seated figures next to a standing man. The rear doorway has a curtain, columns are on the reception desk, the ceiling appears to be beamed, a second painting is on the wall and a stripe is added to the floor. *Study five is double sided. One side appears to be an abandoned diagram of a room. The reverse side shows the room with a more detailed revolving door and a return to a single, framed painting on the wall. The reception desk columns are more detailed, and the stripe on the floor is darkened. *Study six is missing the seated figure from the left with only three remaining and in more detail. The figures and the elevator are in their final locations. *Study seven shows the fourth figure reappearing by the couple. The ceiling, desk, revolving door, curtained doorway and elevator all have greater detail. The couple also appears to be having a conversation. *Study eight was created to further detail the older woman's clothing and hands, showing her with a gold [[glove]]. *Study nine is a partial sketch of the younger woman who is reading, which shares the page with sketch eight, in greater detail. Until this sketch the other seated figure was a man.<ref name="Warkel"/>
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Hotel Lobby by Edward Hopper Detail 3.JPG| thumb| Blonde woman detail]] --> These studies show the older couple communicating, only to cease their conversation in the final painting and reading man is replaced with a blonde young woman reading in the final painting.<ref name="Saetre">{{cite news |title=Fame is no cure for fear, Hopper exhibit shows |author=Julie Cope Saetre |url=http://assets3.indy.com/posts/10478 |newspaper=Indy.com |date=28 August 2008 |accessdate=14 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724055209/http://assets3.indy.com/posts/10478 |archivedate=24 July 2011 |df= }}</ref> The modeling for both women in the painting was done by his wife Josephine. After their marriage in 1920 she insisted on being the model for all of his female figures.<ref name="Elovich">{{cite journal |last1=Elovich |first1=Richard |last2= |first2= |year=1981 |title=London. Edward Hopper |journal=[[The Burlington Magazine]] |volume=123 |issue=935 |pages=111 |publisher=The Burlington Magazine Publications, Inc. |doi= |jstor=880286 }}</ref>
The coat the older woman wears is based on a [[fur coat]] owned by Hopper's wife, a coat she often wore to openings and a rare find in the Hopper's frugal household. <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Hotel Lobby by Edward Hopper Detail 1.JPG| thumb|left| Woman in red detail]] --> The red dress that the older woman wears (that Jo, in her journal, describes as "coral") signifies anger and extroversion, while the blue dress worn by the younger woman shows youth and distance. Throughout Hopper's sketches the clerk does not appear until the final painting. Under X-ray it can be seen that Hopper did little to change the canvas once he began work. Most alterations were made in the position of the young woman's head and in outlines of some areas in dark blue paint. A partial underdrawing was found but little detail remains.
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Hotel Lobby by Edward Hopper Detail 4.JPG| thumb| |Hopper detail]] --> Hopper was known to model for himself for figures, as in ''Nighthawks'', leading some to believe he may have modeled for the male figure in ''Hotel Lobby''.
One of the few paintings by Hopper to lack windows, ''Hotel Lobby'' utilizes light from the revolving door and an unseen area from between the ceiling beams.<ref name="Warkel"/>
==Reception==
In 1945 Hopper was awarded the [[Logan Medal of the Arts]] and a $500 [[honorarium]] for ''Hotel Lobby''.<ref name="Levin">{{cite book |last=Levin |first=Gail |coauthors= |title=Edward Hopper: An intimate biography |publisher=[[University of California Press]] |year=1998 |month= |isbn=0-520-21475-7}}</ref><ref name="ArtInstitute1">{{cite journal |last1=Levin |first1=Gail |last2=Hopper |first2=Edward |year=1996 |title=Edward Hopper's "Nighthawks", Surrealism, and the War |journal=Art Institute of Chicago Museum Studies |volume=22 |issue=2 |pages=195 |publisher=[[Art Institute of Chicago]] |doi= |jstor=4104321 }}</ref> The painting was chosen by a jury composed of [[Juliana Force]], then director of the [[Whitney Museum of American Art|Whitney Museum]], and artists [[Raphael Soyer]] and [[Reginald Marsh (artist)|Reginald Marsh]].<ref name="ArtInstitute1"/> In regards to the painting, Chicago critic [[Clarence Joseph Bulliet|C.J. Bulliet]] stated that "Mr. Hopper is getting a little lazy about the excellent formula he has hit. ''Hotel Lobby'' is typical Hopper, but Hopper that has lost something of its kick."<ref name="Levin"/> The artwork has been compared to Hopper's earlier work ''Summer Interior'' (1909), a work that helped to create Hopper's signature style; an intimate setting, simple lines and geometry, flat color usage and moody light. A shadowy figure and a sensual woman each make another visit in ''Hotel Lobby'' as seen in ''Summer Interior''.<ref name="Warkel"/>
==Ownership and exhibition history== The painting was in the collection of Henry Hope from [[Bloomington, Indiana]].<ref name="HotelLobby"/>
From June until December 2006 the Whitney Museum, which has the largest holding of Hopper's works in the world, displayed ''Hotel Lobby'' alongside their own works and key loans such as ''[[Nighthawks]]'' (1942) and ''New York Movie'' (1939).<ref name="Whitney">{{cite web | author= | year=2011 | title=Edward Hopper | work=Exhibitions | publisher=Whitney Museum of American Art | url=http://whitney.org/Exhibitions/EdwardHopper | accessdate=14 April 2010}}</ref><ref name="Vogel">{{cite news |title=Hoppers Come and Go In a Whitney Show |author=Carol Vogel |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=6 October 2006 }}</ref><ref name="Ronnen">{{cite news |title=Tiroche sale opens tomorrow |author=Meir Ronnen |newspaper=[[The Jerusalem Post]] |date=7 July 2006 }}</ref> ''Hotel Lobby'' is currently on display in the Indianapolis Museum of Art's [[American scene painting|American Scene]] Gallery.<ref name="HotelLobby"/> In 2008 the IMA exhibited the work alongside the ten studies on loan from the Whitney in ''Edward Hopper: Paper to Paint'', which ran until January 2009.<ref name="IndianapolisMonth1"/>
===Publications===
In 1996 ''Hotel Lobby'' was used as the paperback cover for the book ''Hotel Paradise'' by [[Martha Grimes]].<ref name="Grimes">{{cite book |last=Grimes |first=Martha |coauthors= |title=Hotel Paradise |publisher=[[Random House]] |year=1996 |month= |isbn=978-0-345-39425-5}}</ref> The painting also appears in ''City Limits: Crime, consumer culture and the urban experience'' by [[Keith Hayward]].<ref name="Hayward">{{cite book |last=Hayward |first=Keith |coauthors= |title=City limits: Crime, consumer culture and the urban experience |publisher=[[Psychology Press]] |year=2004 |month= |isbn=1-904385-03-6}}</ref>
==See also==
*''[[Automat (painting)|Automat]]'', 1927 *''[[Chop Suey (painting)|Chop Suey]]'', 1929 *''[[Nighthawks]]'', Hopper's most famous painting. *''[[Office at Night]]'', 1940 *''[[Office in a Small City]]'', 1953
==References==
{{reflist|30em}}
==Further reading==
*Tallack, D. (2002). 'Waiting, waiting': the hotel lobby, in the modern city. ''The Hieroglyphics of Space''. [[Psychology Press]]. {{ISBN|978-0-415-19892-9}} Discusses the ideas behind hotel lobbies as symbols of culture, including the painting. *Warkel, Harriet. ''Paper to Paint: Edward Hopper’s "Hotel Lobby."'' [[Indianapolis Museum of Art]]. 2009. {{ISBN|978-0-936260-84-6}} Catalog that coordinated with the 2008 exhibition.
==External links== *[http://huntingnighthawks.blogspot.com/2008/06/13.html ''14 A Hotel Lobby''], Kevin Grandfield talks about his visit to the IMA to view the Hopper's in their collection
