==Other journalists and media workers killed on 9/11== The only professional, working journalist to die while covering the September 11 terrorist attacks on the [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|World Trade Center]] in New York City was photojournalist [[Bill Biggart]], who was killed by falling debris as he was taking photographs.<ref name=irish>{{cite news|first=Conor |last=O'Clery |newspaper=The Irish Times |title=The parting shot |date=December 22, 2001 |url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/weekend/2001/1222/01122200163.html}}</ref><ref name=Newsweek>{{cite news|first=Jerry |last=Adler |title=Shooting To the End |publisher=Newsweek |date=October 15, 2001 |accessdate=February 28, 2013 |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/2001/10/14/shooting-to-the-end.html}}</ref> However, the [[International Federation of Journalists]], which also counts media workers, said that six other media workers and a journalist who were not working at the time died in the attacks. Among those media workers [[Bill Biggart#Context|listed]] as killed were six broadcast TV engineers, who worked inside a tower, and another professional photojournalist, who was a passenger on the first plane that was flown into the WTC.<ref name=CBS2001>{{cite news|title=100 Journalists Killed In 2001 |publisher=CBS News |date=February 11, 2009 |accessdate=March 1, 2011 |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/2100-202_162-321563.html}}</ref>
* Rod Coppola, TV engineer for WNET-TV, WTC (North Tower)<ref name=ifex2001>{{cite news|title=At Pakistan/Afghanistan Border; Journalist Among Dead and Media Workers Missing |publisher=IFEX.org |date=September 25, 2001|url=http://www.ifex.org/2001/09/25/at_pakistan_afghanistan_border/ }}</ref> * Donald DiFranco, TV engineer for WABC-TV, WTC (North Tower)<ref name=ifex2001 /> * Steve Jacobson, TV engineer for WPIX-TV, WTC (North Tower)<ref name=ifex2001 /> * Bob Pattison, TV engineer for WCBS-TV, WTC (North Tower)<ref name=CBS2001 /><ref name=ifex2001 /> * Thomas Pecorelli, professional freelance photojournalist, American Airlines Flight 11 passenger<ref name=CBS2001 /> * Isias Rivera, TV engineer for WCBS-TV, WTC (North Tower)<ref name=CBS2001 /><ref name=ifex2001 /> * William Steckman, TV engineer for WNBC-TV, WTC (North Tower)<ref name=ifex2001 />

A '''literary editor''' is an [[editing|editor]] in a [[newspaper]], [[magazine]] or similar publication who deals with aspects concerning [[literature]] and [[book]]s, especially reviews.<ref>[http://books.guardian.co.uk/booksoftheyear2006/story/0,,1973665,00.html The Literary Editor's pick of the year], ''[[The Observer]]'', Sunday 17 December 2006.</ref> A literary editor may also help with editing books themselves, by providing services such as [[proof reading]], [[copy-editing]], and [[literary criticism]].
==Consulting editor== A '''consulting editor'''<!--REDIRECTS HERE--> is a non-staff, independent literary editor.{{fact|date=July 2011}} A consulting editor may be an independent, freelance editor, or a scholar providing expertise via [[Consultant|consulting]].

'''Maud Edith Cunnington''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|CBE}} (''[[née]]'' Pegge; 24 September 1869 – 28 February 1951) was a [[Wales|Welsh]]-born [[archaeologist]], most famous for her pioneering work on the prehistoric sites of [[Salisbury Plain]].
==Early life and education== Maud Pegge was born at [[Briton Ferry]] in [[Glamorgan]] to Catherine Milton Leach and her husband Charles Pegge, a doctor who ran Vernon House, the last privately owned [[Psychiatric hospital|asylum]] in Wales. She was one of seven children. Cunnington's older brother [[Edward Pegge|Edward]] followed his father as a doctor, and was also a notable rugby player and Welsh international. Maud was educated briefly at [[Cheltenham Ladies' College]].<ref name="ODNB">{{cite book |first=Penelope |last=Rundle |url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/45470 |title=Cunnington, Maud Edith (1869–1951) |work=Oxford Dictionary of National Biography |publisher=Oxford University Press |date=2004}}</ref>
==Career== From 1897, Maud carried out early [[rescue archaeology]] work during development in the area but also carried out full [[Excavation (archaeology)|excavations]] at some of the most important sites in British archaeology. These included the first known Neolithic [[causewayed enclosure]] at [[Knap Hil]], the [[Iron age]] village at [[All Cannings Cross]], [[West Kennet Long Barrow]], [[Figsbury Ring]], [[Woodhenge]],<ref>{{cite book |first=Mike |last=Parker Pearson |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4j23BQAAQBAJ&lpg=PA196&dq=Maud%20Cunnington&pg=PA84#v=onepage&q=Maud%20Cunnington&f=false |title=Stonehenge: A New Understanding: Solving the Mysteries of the Greatest Stone Age Monument |publisher=Workman Publishing |date=2014 |pages=83–85 |isbn=9781615191932}}</ref> and [[The Sanctuary]]. This last monument she rediscovered as it had been lost since [[William Stukeley]] saw it in the eighteenth century. Woodhenge and The Sanctuary were bought by the Cunningtons and given to the nation.<ref>{{cite book |first=Timothy |last=Darvill |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gzEclkBq0u0C&lpg=PT31&dq=Maud%20Cunnington&pg=PT333#v=onepage&q=Maud%20Cunnington&f=false |title=Concise Oxford Dictionary of Archaeology |publisher=Oxford University Press |date=2008 |isbn=9780191579042}}</ref> In 1912 she excavated and re-erected one of the two surviving stones in the Beckhampton Avenue and one of the stones in the West Kennet Avenue at Avebury. In 1933, she was elected president of the [[Wiltshire Archaeological and Natural History Society]], the first woman to hold that position.<ref>{{cite book |first=Sara |last=Champion |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=brj2o4EF_EMC&lpg=PA177&dq=Maud%20Cunnington&pg=PA177#v=onepage&q=Maud%20Cunnington&f=false |chapter=Women in British Archaeology: Visible and Invisible" |editor-first1=Margarita |editor-last1=Diaz-Andreu |editor-first2=Marie Louise Stig |editor-last2=Sorensen, |title=Excavating Women: A History of Women in European Archaeology |publisher=Routledge |date=2005 |page=177 |isbn=9781134727766}}</ref> In addition to technical reports, she published a short handbook, ''Avebury: A Guide'' (1931),<ref>{{cite book |first=Maud E. |last=Cunnington |url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Avebury.html?id=ho5nrgEACAAJ |title=Avebury: A Guide |date=1931}}</ref> and a children's guide to Devizes Museum.<ref>{{cite magazine |first=Susan |last=Greaney |title=Maud Cunnington at Stonehenge |publisher=English Heritage |magazine=English Heritage Members' Magazine |date=April 2018 |page=62}}</ref>
==Personal life== In 1889, Maud Pegge married [[Ben Cunnington (archaeologist)|Ben Cunnington]] who was the honorary curator of [[Devizes]] Museum. Their only son, Edward, was killed in the [[First World War]]. Cunnington was named a Commander of the [[Order of the British Empire]] (CBE) in the [[1948 Birthday Honours]]<ref>{{London Gazette |issue=38311 |date= 10 June 1948 |page=3374 }}</ref> for services to archaeology, the first woman archaeologist to receive the honour. However, she had been bedridden since 1947, and suffering from [[Alzheimer's disease]], so she never knew of the accolade. When she died at home a few years later she left almost all her property (£14,000) to Devizes Museum (now [[Wiltshire Heritage Museum]]), allowing a salaried [[curator]] to be appointed for the first time. Her husband had died a few months earlier.<ref name="ODNB" />
==References== {{reflist}}
==Additional sources== *J. Roberts, "'That Terrible Woman': The Life, Work and Legacy of Maud Cunnington" ''Wiltshire Archaeological and Natural History Magazine'' (2002): 46–62.

The '''Network of African Science Academies''' was formed in December 2001 as an independent forum, for African science academies to discuss scientific issues of common concern.<ref>{{cite web | title=About NASAC | url=http://www.aasciences.org/index.php/About-NASAC/About-NASAC.html | accessdate=2008-03-30}}</ref>
Member academies are: * [[African Academy of Sciences]] * [[Cameroon Academy of Sciences]] * [[Ghana Academy of Arts and Sciences]] * [[Kenya National Academy of Sciences]] * [[Madagascar's National Academy of Arts, Letters and Sciences]] * [[Nigerian Academy of Science]] * [[l'Académie des Sciences et Techniques du Sénégal]] * [[Academy of Science of South Africa]] * [[Sudan Academy of Sciences]] * [[Tanzania Academy of Sciences]] * [[Uganda National Academy of Sciences]] * [[Zambia Academy of Sciences]] * [[Zimbabwe Academy of Sciences]]
==Statement on climate change== In 2007, the Network of African Science Academies submitted a joint “statement on [[sustainability]], [[Efficient energy use|energy efficiency]], and [[climate change]]” to the leaders meeting at the [[G8 Summit]] in Heiligendamm, Germany.
“A [[scientific consensus|consensus]], based on current evidence, now exists within the global [[scientific community]] that human activities are the main source of climate change and that the burning of [[fossil fuels]] is largely responsible for driving this change.”<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web | url=http://www.interacademies.net/File.aspx?id=4825 | title=Joint statement by the Network of African Science Academies (NASAC) to the G8 on sustainability, energy efficiency and climate change | year=2007 | accessdate=2012-08-28 | publisher=Network of African Science Academies |format=PDF}} </ref>

{{no footnotes|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox building | building_name = Ordensburg Krössinsee | image = Bundesarchiv Bild 146-2007-0123, Ordensburg Krössinsee.jpg | caption = Section of Ordensburg Krössinsee | former_name = | location = [[Złocieniec]] | coordinates = | start_date = | completion_date = | status = Complete | building_type = | architectural_style = [[Nazi architecture]] | roof = | top_floor = | floor_count = | room_count = | unit_count = | elevator_count = | cost = | floor_area = | architect = | engineer = | main_contractor = | developer = | owner = [[Polish Armed Forces]] | management = | references = }} '''Ordensburg Krössinsee''' (also ''Crössinsee'') was the first of three ''[[NS-Ordensburgen]]'', educational centers constructed in [[Germany]] in the 1930s for [[cadres]] of the [[Nazi Party]]. It was built near what was then the city of Falkenburg in [[Pomerania]], today [[Złocieniec]] in [[Poland]].
Today, this former Nazi training centre is used by the 2nd Battalion, 12th Tank Brigade of the [[Polish Land Forces]].
== History ==
The groundbreaking for ''Ordensburg Krössinsee'' was on 22 April 1934. It was designed by the Cologne architect [[Clemens Klotz]]. The vast construction of rustic stone buildings with granite foundations was built at a cost of 20 million Reichsmarks, and the facility was officially dedicated on 24 April 1936. On 16 May 1941, the ''Ordensburg'' was renamed '''"Die Falkenburg am Krössinsee"''' (The Castle Falkenburg at Lake Krössin) by the Reichs Minister of Labor, Dr. [[Robert Ley|Ley, Robert]]. On 29 June 1944, a small portion of the complex was destroyed by fire.
''Ordensburg Krössinsee'' was one of three ''NS-Ordensburgen'', the others being [[Ordensburg Sonthofen]] in [[Allgäu]] and [[Ordensburg Vogelsang]] in [[Eifel]]. A fourth was planned, but never built, at (the historic) [[Ordensburg Marienburg]] in [[West Prussia]], known today as [[Malbork Castle]] in [[Poland]].
==Student requirements== [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 102-17964, Ordensburg Krössinsee, Herzog von Windsor.jpg|thumb|[[Edward VIII of the United Kingdom|Edward, the Duke of Windsor]] on a visit to the ''Ordensburg Krössinsee'' 1937 (together with [[Robert Ley]] on the left in a white coat)]] The Commander of the [[Ordensburg]] was Otto Gohdes. Cadets, known as Ordens Junkers, were required to be at least {{convert|5|ft|4|in|m}}, between 23 and 26 years old, racially pure and in good health without any physical limitations. At the outbreak of [[World War II]], a very high percentage of Junkers were killed in action.
==Daily routine==
Two courses of studies took place here from 1937–38 and 1938-39. Classes began each morning at 7 and included studies in philosophy, politics and world history. Afternoons were devoted to military drills, battle tactics, sports and equestrian techniques. The school was recognized for its outstanding equestrian program. The nearby lake provided the means for students to develop rowing and sailing skills.
==Hitler Youth==
In 1937, the cadres began sharing the facility with members of the Hitlerjungen or [[Hitler Youth]]. These boys between 12–18 years old eventually became the sole occupants of all three Order Castles with the [[Invasion of Poland (1939)|invasion of Poland]] in 1939 and the start of World War II.
==Facility details== '''Finished Facilities:''' {| width="100%" | * Hall of Honour (Ehrenhalle) * Ceremonial place (Feierplatz) * 20 living quarters * Sports field * [[Appeal field]] * Drill ground * Riding arena with barns * Community house * Dining-hall * Educational hall * Dwelling for the commander * House for the female employees * Buildings for the administration * Seminar rooms * Sick bay * Pig breeding * Clarification plant * Two towers (four were planned) |}
'''Planned, but not Realized Facilities:''' {| width="100%" | * Hotel * Swimming pool * Water sports facility |}
==Time capsule== During the construction of the ''Ordensburg Krössinsee'', a copper cylinder [[time capsule]] was buried in the foundation of one of the towers, presumably in April 1934 when construction of the Nazi facility commenced. The capsule was opened by archaeologists in 2016, more than 80 years after it had been buried. Although the archeologists had long known that the time capsule was buried in the building foundation, they were not able to access it until 2016, and had to wade through groundwater, cut through thick concrete and evade potential German mines in order to reach it.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Platt|first1=Gareth|title=Nazi time capsule from 1934 found buried in Third Reich training school |url=http://talkradio.co.uk/news/nazi-time-capsule-1934-found-buried-third-reich-training-school-1609164215|accessdate=19 September 2016|publisher=[[Talkradio]]|date=16 September 2016|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6kduYXm70|archivedate=19 September 2016}}</ref>
Unlike many time capsules, the contents of which are often damaged or destroyed by water, the contents of this capsule were perfectly preserved. The contents included photographs (including images of [[Adolf Hitler]]), newspapers from 1934, coins, books (including two copies of [[Mein Kampf]]), and promotional and historical materials about what was then the town of Falkenburg. The contents were transferred to the [[National Museum, Szczecin|National Museum in Szczecin]] for cataloguing, translation, preservation and display.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Eleftheriou-Smith|first1=Loulla-Mae|title=Nazi time capsule: Newspapers, photographs and copies of Mein Kampf found ‘perfectly preserved’ in Poland|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/nazi-time-capsule-poland-mein-kampf-adolf-hitler-discovery-photos-a7315771.html|accessdate=19 September 2016|publisher=[[The Independent]]|date=18 September 2016|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6kduXhDw5|archivedate=19 September 2016}}</ref>

{{BLP sources|date=November 2014}} {{infobox academic | name = Orlando Patterson | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1940|06|05|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Westmoreland, Jamaica|Westmoreland]], [[Jamaica]] | home_town = [[May Pen]], Jamaica | title = John Cowles Chair in Sociology at [[Harvard University]] | awards = {{ubl|[[National Book Award]]|[[Musgrave Medal]]|[[Anisfield-Wolf Book Award]]}} | education = {{ubl|[[University of the West Indies]]|[[London School of Economics]]}} | doctoral_advisor = [[David Glass (sociologist)|David Glass]] | discipline = [[sociology|Sociologist]] | workplaces = Harvard University | main_interests = {{hlist|[[Race and ethnicity in the United States|Race in the US]]|[[Economic development]]}} | notable_works = ''Freedom in the Making of Western Culture'' (1991) }}
'''Orlando Patterson''' (born 5 June 1940) is a [[Jamaica]]n-born [[United States|America]]n historical and cultural sociologist known for his work regarding issues of [[Race (classification of human beings)|race]] in the [[United States]], as well as the sociology of development. His book ''Freedom, Volume One'', or ''Freedom in the Making of Western Culture'' (1991), won the U.S. [[National Book Award for Nonfiction]].<ref name=nba1991>[https://www.nationalbook.org/awards-prizes/national-book-awards-1991 "National Book Awards – 1991"]. [[National Book Foundation]]. Retrieved 24 March 2012.</ref>
==Early life and education== Patterson was born in [[Westmoreland, Jamaica]], and grew up in [[Clarendon Parish, Jamaica|Clarendon Parish]] in the small town of [[May Pen]]. He attended primary school there, then moved to [[Kingston, Jamaica|Kingston]] to attend Kingston College. He went on to earn a BSc in Economics from the [[University of the West Indies]], [[Mona, Jamaica|Mona]], in 1962, and his Ph.D. in Sociology at the [[London School of Economics]] in 1965.<ref>[http://www.peepaltreepress.com/author_display.asp?au_id=179 Author information at Peepal Tree Press.]</ref> His dissertation adviser was [[David Glass (sociologist)|David Glass]]. While in London he was associated with the [[Caribbean Artists Movement]], whose second meeting, in January 1967, was held at the Patterson's North London flat.<ref>[[Anne Walmsley]], ''The Caribbean Artists Movement, 1966-1972: A Literary and Cultural History'', [[New Beacon Books]], 1992, p. 51. {{ISBN|978-1873201060}}.</ref>
==Career== Earlier in his career, Patterson was concerned with the economic and political development of his home country, [[Jamaica]]. He served as special advisor to [[Michael Manley]], [[Prime Minister of Jamaica]], from 1972 to 1979.
Patterson is known for his work on the relationship between slavery and [[social death]], which he has worked on extensively and written several books about.
Patterson has appeared on [[PBS]] and has been a guest columnist in ''[[The New York Times]]''. A recent article in the latter, "The Real Problem With America’s Inner Cities," used the lens of developmental sociology to analyze recent protests and looting in West Baltimore.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Patterson|first1=Orlando|title=The Real Problem in America's Inner Cities|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/10/opinion/sunday/the-real-problem-with-americas-inner-cities.html?_r=0|work=The New York Times|date=9 May 2015}}</ref>
Patterson currently holds the John Cowles chair in Sociology at [[Harvard University]].
In October 2015 he received the Gold [[Musgrave Medal]] in recognition of his contribution to literature.<ref>"[http://jamaica-gleaner.com/article/entertainment/20151030/gold-sly-and-robbie Gold for Sly and Robbie]", ''[[Jamaica Gleaner]]'', 30 October 2015. Retrieved 1 November 2015.</ref>
==Professional associations==
* Fellow, [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] * [[Ernest W. Burgess Fellow]], [[American Academy of Political and Social Science]] * Member, [[American Sociological Association]] *Board of Directors, [http://nycivilrights.org New York Civil Rights Coalition]
==Awards==
* [[Walter Channing Cabot Faculty Prize]], Harvard, 1997 * [[National Book Award]], Non-Fiction, 1991<ref name=nba1991/> * [[Distinguished Contribution to Scholarship]] (formerly [[Sorokin Prize]]): [[American Sociological Association]], 1983 * [[Ralph Bunche Award]] from [[Howard University]] for the Best Scholarly Work on Pluralism (co-winner): American * [[Political Science Association]], 1983 * Walter Channing Cabot Faculty Prize, Harvard, 1983/1997 * Best Novel in English (''The Children of Sisyphus''): [[World Festival of Black Arts|Dakar Festival of Negro Arts]], 1965 * Gold [[Musgrave Medal]], 2015 * [[Anisfield-Wolf Book Award]], Lifetime Achievement, 2016
==Selected bibliography== * ''The Children of Sisyphus'' (novel). 1965. * ''An Absence of Ruins'' (novel). 1967. * ''The Sociology of Slavery''. 1967. * ''An Analysis of the Origins, Development and Structure of Negro Slave Society in Jamaica''. 1968. * ''Die the Long Day'' (novel). 1972. * ''Ethnic Chauvinism: The Reactionary Impulse''. 1977. * {{cite book | title=Slavery and Social Death | year=1982}} * {{cite book | title=Freedom in the Making of Western Culture| year=1991}} Later renamed ''Freedom, Vol. 1: Freedom in the Making of Western Culture'' — winner of National Book Award<ref name=nba1991/> * {{cite book | title=Rituals of Blood: Consequences of Slavery in Two American Centuries| year=1999}} * {{cite book | title=Freedom: Freedom in the Modern World | year=2006}} * ''The Cultural Matrix: Understanding Black Youth'' (with Ethan Fosse). 2015.
==References== {{reflist}}

Support for the far-right and Islamophobic organisation is more keenly seen in Dutch-speaking Flanders, than in francophone Wallonia and Brussels.}} * {{cite Anderson|title=Immigration, Assimilation, and the Cultural Construction of American National Identity|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=snn4CgAAQBAJ&pg=PT16|date=19 November 2015|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-1-317-32875-9|page=16|quote=In Germany, the far-right anti-Islam movement Pegida found massive audience in its anti-Islamic, anti-immigration marches}} * {{cite news|title=Anti-Islam Organization PEGIDA Is Exporting Hate Across Europe|url=http://www.newsweek.com/anti-islam-organization-pegida-exporting-hate-across-europe-426805|publisher=Newsweek|quote=The 200 or so demonstrators trudging down the road are supporters of PEGIDA, a far-right German group whose name is an acronym for Patriotic Europeans Against the Islamization of the Occident.}} * {{cite news|title=France bans march through Calais by far-right Pegida group|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/france-bans-march-through-calais-by-far-right-pegida-group-1541766|publisher=ibtimes.co.uk}} * {{cite news|title=Germany's refugee crisis is fueling the far-right Pegida movement|url=http://www.pri.org/stories/2015-12-10/germany-s-refugee-crisis-fueling-far-right-pegida-movement|publisher=pri.org}} * {{cite news|title=Germany reveals plans to relax deportation rules for foreign criminals|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/01/12/europe/germany-cologne-migrants-tensions/|publisher=CNN|quote=Protesters from the far-right PEGIDA movement attend a rally in Leipzig on Monday}} Founded in [[Dresden]] in October 2014, Pegida believes that Germany is being increasingly Islamicized{{cite news|author1=SPIEGEL Staff|title=The End of Tolerance? Anti-Muslim Movement Rattles Germany|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/germany/anti-muslim-pegida-movement-rattles-germany-a-1009245.html|accessdate=3 January 2015|work=Der Spiegel|date=21 December 2014}} and defines itself in opposition to [[Islamic extremism]]. Pegida wants to curb immigration, and accuses authorities of not enforcing existing immigration laws.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-30776182|title=Who goes to German Pegida 'anti-Islamisation' rallies|publisher=BBC News|date=13 January 2015}} Pegida has held many demonstrations; often there have been many public demonstrations against them as well.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/germany-antiislam-protests-biggest-pegida-march-ever-in-dresden-as-rest-of-germany-shows-disgust-9959301.html|title=Germany anti-Islamic protests: Biggest Pegida march ever in Dresden as rest of Germany shows disgust with lights-out|newspaper=The Independent|date=5 January 2015}} In 2015, the founder of Pegida resigned after being reported as having posed as Adolf Hitler and having made racist statements on Facebook.{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/germany/11375165/Germanys-Pegida-anti-Islam-movement-unravelling.html|title=Germany's Pegida anti-Islam movement unravelling|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=28 January 2015}} He was later reinstated.{{cite news|title=Pegida head Lutz Bachmann reinstated after furore over Hitler moustache photo|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/feb/23/pegida-head-lutz-bachmann-reinstated-hitler-moustache-photo|first1=Ben|last1=Knight|newspaper=The Guardian|date=23 February 2015|accessdate=31 October 2015}} Offshoots of Pegida have been formed in [[Pegida#Fortress Europe|various countries]]. ==History== ===Origin=== [[File:Pegida-Plakat.svg|thumb|left|Alternate logo used by Pegida.{{cite news|last=Bremer|first=Nils|title=Auch die Gegner organisieren sich|url=http://www.journal-frankfurt.de/journal_news/Politik-10/Auch-die-Gegner-organisieren-sich-Fragida-plant-Hallenveranstaltung-23460.html|accessdate=21 June 2016|work=Journal Frankfurt|date=5 January 2015}} Slogans such as "Violence-free and united against religious and [[proxy war]]s on German soil" are commonplace at Pegida rallies.{{cite news|last=Iskandar|first=Katharina|title=Auch die Gegner organisieren sich|url=http://www.faz.net/aktuell/rhein-main/pegida-demo-in-frankfurt-wuetender-protest-am-zaun-13392183.html|accessdate=21 June 2016|work=[[Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung]]|date=27 January 2015}}{{cite news|last=Weiß|first=Volker|title=Islam-Gegner und rechte Szene: Pegida ist die neue Abkürzung für "Ausländer raus"|url=http://www.spiegel.de/kultur/gesellschaft/pegida-die-neue-abkuerzung-fuer-auslaender-raus-a-1007914.html|accessdate=21 June 2016|work=[[Der Spiegel]]|date=12 December 2014}}]] Pegida was founded in October 2014 by [[Lutz Bachmann]], who runs a [[public relations]] agency in [[Dresden]].{{cite news|last=Connolly|first=Kate|title=Estimated 15,000 people join ‘pinstriped Nazis’ on march in Dresden|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/dec/15/dresden-police-pegida-germany-far-right|accessdate=4 January 2015|work=The Guardian|date=15 December 2014}} Bachmann's impetus for starting Pegida was witnessing a rally by alleged supporters of the [[Kurdistan Workers' Party]] (PKK) against the siege of [[Kobani]] by the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|Islamic State]] (ISIL) on 10 October 2014 in Dresden,{{cite web|url=http://www.bild.de/regional/dresden/demonstrationen/pegida-erfinder-im-interview-38780422.bild.html |title=PEGIDA-Erfinder: Wir hören erst auf, wenn die Asyl-Politik sich ändert! - Dresden |publisher=Bild.de |date=1 December 2014 |accessdate=17 February 2015|language=de}} which he posted on YouTube on the same day.{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d6aFr9GVE2c |title=KURDEN DEMO DRESDEN |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website=Youtube |publisher=Lutz Bachmann |accessdate= 5 January 2015|language=German}} The next day he founded a [[Facebook group]] called ''{{lang|de|Patriotische Europäer Gegen die Islamisierung des Abendlandes}}'' ("Patriotic Europeans against Islamisation of the Occident").{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/germany/origins-of-german-anti-muslim-group-pegida-a-1012522.html|title=Prying into Pegida: Where Did Germany's Islamophobes Come From?|last1=Popp|first1=Maximilian|last2=Wassermann|first2=Andreas|work=[[Der Spiegel]]|date=12 January 2015|accessdate=16 January 2015}} A few days earlier, on 7 October, a group of Muslims, assumed to be [[Salafi movement|Salafists]], had violently attacked alleged PKK supporters who were gathering after a demonstration against ISIL.{{cite news|title=Pro-ISIS radicals with machetes, knives attack Kurds in Germany|url=http://rt.com/news/194060-germany-kurds-muslims-brawls/|date=8 October 2014|accessdate=16 January 2015|work=[[RT (TV network)|RT.com]]}} The same day, [[Yazidis]] and Muslim [[Chechens]] had violently clashed in [[Celle]].{{cite news|title=Germany: Holy War Erupts in Hamburg|url=http://www.gatestoneinstitute.org/4780/hamburg-holy-war|date=15 October 2014|accessdate=16 January 2015|work=[[Gatestone Institute]]}} On 26 October, out of 5,000 protesters, "at least 400 right-wing extremists went on a rampage in downtown [[Cologne]] during a demonstration" by "[[Hogesa|Hooligans Against Salafists]]". Bachmann mentioned these events in a release for his first demonstration.{{cite web|url=http://www.faz.net/aktuell/politik/inland/pegida-bewegung-gegen-islamisierung-des-abendlandes-13306852.html |title=Pegida: Bewegung gegen Islamisierung des Abendlandes |publisher=Faz.net |date=25 January 2016 |accessdate=7 February 2016}} ===First wave of demonstrations=== The first demonstration, or "evening stroll" (according to Pegida), took place on 20 October 2014, and only attracted a handful of people. During the following days, the movement began gaining wider public attention, and, subsequently, the weekly Monday demonstrations drew larger numbers of people. Among the 7,500 participants on 1 December 2014, the police identified 80 to 120 [[hooliganism|hooligans]]. The demonstration grew to 10,000 people on 8 December 2014.{{cite news|last1=Smale|first1=Alison|title=In German City Rich With History and Tragedy, Tide Rises Against Immigration|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/08/world/in-german-city-rich-with-history-and-tragedy-tide-rises-against-immigration.html|accessdate=16 December 2014|publisher=New York Times|date=7 December 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Kirschbaum|first1=Erik|title=Patriotic Europeans Against the Islamisation of the West quickly gathering support in Germany|url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/patriotic-europeans-against-the-islamisation-of-the-west-quickly-gathering-support-in-germany-20141216-128105.html|accessdate=16 December 2014|publisher=Sydney Morning Herald|date=16 December 2014}} During the weekly demonstrations on Monday evenings, Pegida supporters carried banners with slogans such as "For the preservation of our culture," "Against religious fanaticism, against any kind of radicalism, together without violence," and "Against religious wars on German soil."{{cite news|last1=Stute|first1=Dennis|title=Anti-Islamist protests with right-wing ties expand in Germany|url=http://www.dw.de/anti-islamist-protests-with-right-wing-ties-expand-in-germany/a-18113657|accessdate=9 December 2014|work=[[Deutsche Welle]]|date=7 December 2014}} On 19 December 2014, PEGIDA e.V. was legally registered in Dresden under the registration ID ''VR 7750'',{{cite web|url=https://mopo24.de/nachrichten/dresdner-tafel-will-kein-geld-von-pegida-3300|title=Dresdner Tafel will kein Geld von PEGIDA|work=Morgenpost Sachsen|date=22 December 2014|accessdate=17 January 2015}} with Bachmann as chairman, Rene Jahn as vice-chairman, and [[Kathrin Oertel]] as treasurer. Pegida also formally applied for the status of a [[nonprofit organization]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bild.de/regional/dresden/pegida/so-will-pegida-mit-den-demos-geld-machen-39313292.bild.html|title=So will Pegida mit den Demos Geld machen|work=[[Bild]]|last=Fischer|first=Christian|date=12 January 2015|accessdate=17 January 2015|language=de}} ===Aftermath of ''Charlie Hebdo'' and rising tensions=== [[File:PEGIDA DRESDEN DEMO 12 Jan 2015 115724030.jpg|thumb|Pegida demonstration on 12 January 2015 after the [[Charlie Hebdo shooting|''Charlie Hebdo'' shooting]]]] While the demonstration on 29 December 2014 was cancelled by the organizers, the movement continued to draw large numbers of participants in early January 2015. After the [[Charlie Hebdo shooting|''Charlie Hebdo'' shooting]] on 7 January 2015 in Paris, politicians (including ministers [[Thomas de Maiziere]] and [[Heiko Maas]]) warned Pegida against misusing the attack on ''Charlie Hebdo'' for its own political ends. On Saturday 10 January 2015 some 35,000{{cite web|url=http://www.mdr.de/sachsen/demonstrationen-in-dresden-und-bautzen100.html |title=35.000 Dresdner demonstrieren für Toleranz |publisher=MDR.DE |date=13 January 2015 |accessdate=17 February 2015}} anti-Pegida protesters gathered to mourn the victims of Paris, observing a [[minute's silence]] in front of the [[Dresden Frauenkirche|Frauenkirche]]. On 12 January 2015, Pegida organizers organized a rally of some 25,000 participants. Pegida's main organizer, Bachmann, declared the six central political objectives of Pegida, which include calls for selective immigration and the expulsion of religious extremists, the right and duty to integrate, and tighter internal security.{{cite web|title=Record turnout at Dresden PEGIDA rally sees more than 25,000 march|url=http://www.dw.de/record-turnout-at-dresden-pegida-rally-sees-more-than-25000-march/a-18186820|first=Kate|last=Brady|work=[[Deutsche Welle]]|date=12 January 2015|accessdate=17 January 2015}} On 15 January 2015, a young [[Eritrea]]n immigrant, [[Murder of Khaled Idris Bahray|Khaled Idris Bahray]], was found stabbed to death in his Dresden high-rise apartment. International media correspondents portrayed an "atmosphere of hatred and resentment" and published social media comments of Pegida sympathizers, who had expressed disdain for the dead Eritrean. Pegida's organizers rejected any possible connection.{{cite web|title=Killing of Eritrean refugee in Dresden exposes racial tensions in Germany|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jan/15/pegida-dresden-eritrean-refugee-murder-far-right-germany|work=''[[The Guardian]]''|first=Kate|last=Connolly|date=15 January 2015|accessdate=17 January 2015}} One week later, the police investigation led to the arrest and eventual conviction of one of the victim's Eritrean housemates.{{cite web|title=Arrest made over the death of Dresden asylum seeker|work=[[Deutsche Welle]]|url=http://www.dw.de/arrest-made-over-the-death-of-dresden-asylum-seeker/a-18209972|date=22 January 2015|accessdate=22 January 2015}}{{cite web|title=Fünf Jahre Haft wegen Totschlags|work=MDR Sachsen |url=http://www.mdr.de/sachsen/dresden/urteil-khaled-prozess100.html |date=6 November 2015|accessdate=26 January 2016}} [[File:PEGIDA Demo DRESDEN 25 Jan 2015 116227086.jpg|thumb|Pegida demonstration on 25 January 2015]] Dresden police did not permit the demonstration planned for 19 January 2015, due to a definite threat against one of Pegida's leadership members in form of an Arabic-language [[Twitter|tweet]] labelling Pegida an "enemy of Islam".{{cite news|last1=Sommers|first1=Jack |title=Pegida Cancel Lastest [sic] Dresden Demonstration After Threats|work=Huffington Post UK| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2015/01/18/pegida-cancel-dresden-demo_n_6496262.html|accessdate=19 January 2015|publisher=AOL (UK) Limited|date=18 January 2015}} Pegida cancelled its 13th demonstration and stated in a post on its Facebook page that there was an explicit threat against a leadership member, and "his execution had been ordered by ISIS terrorists".{{cite news|title=Dresdner Polizei verbietet Demos wegen Anschlagsgefahr| url=http://de.reuters.com/article/topNews/idDEKBN0KR0N620150118|accessdate=19 January 2015|work=Reuters|publisher=Thomson Reuters|date=18 January 2015}} Nonetheless, the Pegida demonstrations resumed in full force in the summer and autumn of 2015, with 10,000 demonstrators attending a rally in September.{{cite web|title = Germany faces massive anti-migrant vs. pro-migrant standoff amid refugee crisis|url = http://www.rt.com/news/314684-germany-protests-migrants-pegida/|accessdate = 1 October 2015}} ===Resignations=== On 21 January 2015, Bachmann resigned from his position with Pegida after coming under fire for a number of Facebook posts.{{cite web|title=German populist leader quits after Hitler pose emerges|first=Stefan|last=Wagstyl|work=[[Financial Times]]|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/4b28b384-a154-11e4-bd03-00144feab7de.html|date=21 January 2015|accessdate=21 January 2015}} Excerpts from a closed Facebook conversation incriminated Bachmann as having designated immigrants as "animals", "scumbags"{{Cite news |url=http://www.dw.de/pegida-founder-bachmann-quits-after-hitler-mustache-photo/a-18207351 |title=PEGIDA founder Bachmann quits after Hitler mustache photo |publisher=DW |date=21 January 2015}} and "trash", classified as [[hate speech]] in Germany. He was also quoted commenting that extra security was needed at the welfare office "to protect employees from the animals".{{cite news|title=German PEGIDA leader investigated after Hitler pose|first=Madeline|last=Chambers|work=[[Reuters]]|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/01/21/germany-islam-pegida-idUSL6N0V02VI20150121|date=21 January 2015|accessdate=21 January 2015}} A self-portrait of Bachmann allegedly posing as a reincarnation of [[Adolf Hitler]], titled "He's back!" (which the ''[[Sächsische Zeitung]]'' later discovered to be a forgery, reporting that a moustache was added after the photo was taken), went viral in social media{{cite web|title=Photograph of Germany’s Pegida leader styled as Adolf Hitler goes viral|first=Kate|last=Connolly|work=''[[The Guardian]]''|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jan/21/pegida-leader-styled-adolf-hitler-lutz-bachmann-german-islamist-terrorists-facebook|date=21 January 2015|accessdate=21 January 2015}} and was printed on title pages worldwide. On another occasion, Bachmann had posted a photo of a man wearing the uniform of the US white supremacist organisation [[Ku Klux Klan]] accompanied by the slogan: "Three Ks a day keeps the minorities away". The Dresden state prosecutors opened an investigation for suspected ''[[Volksverhetzung]]'' (incitement), and [[Vice-Chancellor of Germany|Deputy Chancellor]] [[Sigmar Gabriel]] said the real face of Pegida had been exposed: "Anyone who puts on a Hitler disguise is either an idiot or a Nazi. People should think carefully about running after a [[Pied Piper of Hamelin|Pied Piper]] like this". ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' reported that Pegida's media spokeswoman, [[Kathrin Oertel]], turned to the [[Alternative for Germany|AfD]] for advice, and that the ''[[Sächsische Zeitung]]'' and ''[[Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung]]'' both confirmed there was a phone conversation between the AfD's [[Frauke Petry]] and Oertel. Petry said to Oertel that Bachmann should no longer be supported ("Ich habe ihr gesagt, dass Bachmann nicht mehr zu halten ist"). On that same day Oertel announced Bachmann's resignation.{{cite news|title=Skandal um Lutz Bachmann: AfD beriet Pegida in Hitler-Affäre|url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/afd-beriet-pegida-in-der-hitler-affaere-von-lutz-bachmann-a-1014623.html|accessdate=23 February 2016|work=[[Der Spiegel]]|date=23 January 2015}} On 28 January, Oertel resigned as well, citing "the massive hostility, threats and career disadvantages" as the reason.{{cite web|title=German anti-Islam group PEGIDA loses second leader in a week|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2015/01/28/uk-germany-islam-pegida-idUKKBN0L11TI20150128|first1=Stephen|last1=Brown|first2=Alexandra|last2=Hudson|work=[[Reuters]]|date=28 January 2015|accessdate=28 January 2015}} At the same time four other leading figures of Pegida stepped back.{{cite web|title=Germany Pegida: Leader Kathrin Oertel quits protest group|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-31018097|work=[[BBC News]]|date=28 January 2015|accessdate=28 January 2015}} On 2 February 2015 Oertel and six other former Pegida members founded '[[Direkte Demokratie für Europa]]' (Direct Democracy for Europe) to distance themselves from the far-right tendencies of Pegida".{{cite news|author1=Kate Connolly|title=Former Pegida head starts ‘less radical’ splinter group|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/feb/03/ex-pegida-leader-forms-breakaway-group|accessdate=16 February 2015|work=The Guardian|date=3 February 2015}} ===Reinstatement=== In February 2015, Pegida confirmed on its Facebook page that Lutz Bachmann had been re-elected as chairman by the six other members of the organisation’s leadership committee, after the [[Sächsische Zeitung]] published a report that the Hitler moustache on the now infamous photo had been added after the photo was taken. ===Dresden mayoral election, 2015=== In June 2015, following the resignation of [[Christian Democratic Union of Germany|CDU]] [[incumbent]] Helma Orosz on health grounds, [[Tatjana Festerling]], who was dismissed from Pegida's leadership circle in June 2016,{{cite news|last=|first=|title=Bachmann stellt Vertrauensfrage|url=http://www.sz-online.de/nachrichten/bachmann-stellt-vertrauensfrage-3424871.html|accessdate=27 June 2016|work=[[Sächsische Zeitung]]|date=20 June 2016}} ran for the mayoral office of Dresden, polling 9.6% in the first round with support from the far-right [[National Democratic Party of Germany|NPD]].{{cite news|title=Merkel's CDU suffers setback in Dresden mayoral poll|url=http://www.dw.de/merkels-cdu-suffers-setback-in-dresden-mayoral-poll/a-18502009|accessdate=8 June 2015|publisher=Deutsche Welle|date=8 June 2013}} On 7 July 2015, group leader Bachmann announced that Pegida would participate in all future federal elections in Germany.{{cite web|url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/politik/islamfeindliche-bewegung-pegida-will-bei-landtagswahlen-antreten-1.2554454 |title=Pegida will bei Landtagswahlen antreten - Politik - Süddeutsche.de |publisher=Sueddeutsche.de |date=7 July 2015 |accessdate=7 February 2016}} ===Renewed protests=== [[File:2014-05-10 Akif Pirinçci IMG 1437.jpg|thumb|130px|upright|Pegida keynote speaker [[Akif Pirinçci]], who has since been charged with [[Volksverhetzung|incitement to hatred]]]] The [[European migrant crisis]] revived the movement, which drew as many as 20,000 supporters to a 19 October 2015 rally in Dresden.{{cite news|last1=Smale|first1=Alison|title=Anti-Immigrant Violence in Germany Spurs New Debate on Hate Speech|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/22/world/europe/anti-immigrant-refugees-violence-in-germany.html?ref=europe|accessdate=22 October 2015|publisher=New York Times|date=21 October 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Huggler|first1=Justin|title=Warnings over resurgence of German far-Right movement Pegida sparked by refugee crisis|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/germany/11943492/Warnings-over-resurgence-of-German-far-Right-movement-Pegida-sparked-by-refugee-crisis.html|accessdate=22 October 2015|publisher=The Daily Telegraph|date=20 October 2015}} At the same time, observers perceived a further [[radicalisation]] of the crowd.{{cite web |author=Janosch Delcker |title=German anti-immigrant protests revive — and radicalize |work=[[Politico Europe]] |url=http://www.politico.eu/article/german-anti-immigrant-protests-revive-and-radicalize/ |date=6 October 2015 |accessdate=20 October 2015}} On 28 September, two journalists were injured when Pegida participants kicked a local newspaper reporter and punched another TV reporter in the face.{{cite news |title=Two Journalists Injured While Reporting On Pegida Movement In Germany |date=1 October 2015 |work=The Typewriter }} On 12 October, Pegida demonstrators carried a mock gallows showing nooses reserved for Chancellor [[Angela Merkel]] and her deputy [[Sigmar Gabriel]].{{cite news |title=Germany: prosecutors probe mock gallows at PEGIDA rally |work=[[Washington Post]] |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/germany-prosecutors-probe-mock-gallows-at-pegida-rally/2015/10/13/f29c989e-7195-11e5-ba14-318f8e87a2fc_story.html |date=13 October 2015 |accessdate=20 October 2015}} Bachmann derided the demonstrators who made this, calling it a "laughable piece of work with spelling errors" ("lächerliche Bastelarbeit mit Schreibfehlern"), a reference to the fact that the name Sigmar had been written with an "ie" (Siegmar).{{cite news|title=Lächerliche Bastelarbeit mit Schreibfehlern|url=http://www.stern.de/politik/pegida-dresden--lutz-bachman-versteht-wirbel-um-galgen-nicht-6498442.html|accessdate=25 January 2016|work=[[Stern (magazine)|Stern]]|date=13 October 2015}} At Pegida's anniversary event on 19 October 2015, keynote speaker [[Akif Pirinçci]] named the Muslim refugees as invaders, with Germany becoming a "Muslim garbage dump".{{cite news |title=Warnings over resurgence of German far-Right movement Pegida sparked by refugee crisis |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/germany/11943492/Warnings-over-resurgence-of-German-far-Right-movement-Pegida-sparked-by-refugee-crisis.html |work=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] |date=20 October 2015 |accessdate=20 October 2015}} Pirinçci said that politicians were acting like "[[Gauleiter]] against their own people",{{cite news|title=Eklat bei Pegida-Demo: "Die KZs sind ja leider derzeit außer Betrieb"|url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/akif-pirincci-rede-bei-pegida-in-dresden-abgebrochen-a-1058589.html|accessdate=5 March 2016|work=[[Der Spiegel]]|date=20 October 2015}} as they wanted critics of Germany's refugee policy to leave the country. Addressing the crowd shouting "Resistance!", he claimed that the majority of Germans were held in contempt by the political class and that politicians wished that there were "other alternatives [to fight Pegida supporters{{cite web |title=Die Unwahrheit über Akif Pirinçcis "KZ-Rede"|last=Niggemeier|first=Stefan|work=[[Journalist]]|url=http://www.stefan-niggemeier.de/blog/22191/die-unwahrheit-ueber-akif-pirincis-kz-rede/|date=1 November 2015 |accessdate=5 March 2016}}] – but the [[Nazi concentration camps|concentration camps]] are unfortunately out of order at the moment".{{cite web |title=Germany’s PEGIDA condemned over ‘concentration camp’ speech |url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/germanys-pegida-condemned-over-concentration-camp-speech/ |work=[[Times of Israel]] |date=20 October 2015 |accessdate=20 October 2015}} The crowd applauded and laughed, and let him continue his speech for another 20 minutes before calling upon him to finish.{{cite news |title=Outrage over concentration camp quip at PEGIDA speech |url=http://www.dw.com/en/outrage-over-concentration-camp-quip-at-pegida-speech/a-18793051 |work=[[Deutsche Welle]] |date=20 October 2015 |accessdate=20 October 2015}} When 1,500 to 2,000 people celebrated Pegida in Leipzig's first anniversary, dozens of hooligans went on a rampage, vandalizing foreign-owned shops. Over 100 people were arrested.{{cite web |title=Over 100 arrested, shops vandalized in Leipzig amid LEGIDA birthday demonstrations (VIDEO)|work=[[Russia Today]]|url=https://www.rt.com/news/328586-legida-anti-migrant-demonstration-rampage/|date=12 January 2016 |accessdate=5 March 2016}} Mayor Burghard Jung called it "open street terror".{{cite web|url=http://www.dw.com/en/leipzig-police-arrest-hundreds-after-far-right-hooligans-violent-rampage/a-18974153|title=Leipzig police arrest hundreds after far-right hooligans' violent rampage - News - DW.COM - 12.01.2016|first=Deutsche Welle|last=(www.dw.com)|publisher=}} === Party founding === The founder of Pegida, Lutz Bachmann, has set up a new political party, the ''Freiheitlich Direktdemokratische Volkspartei'' ("Liberal Direct Democratic People's Party", or "FDDV"). The FDDV was established on 13 June 2016.{{cite web | last=GmbH | first=Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung | title=Dresden: Pegida-Anhänger gründen offenbar eigene Partei | website=FAZ.NET | date=19 July 2016 | url=http://www.faz.net/aktuell/politik/inland/lutz-bachmann-hat-angeblich-eine-pegida-partei-gegruendet-14348098.html | language=de | accessdate=19 July 2016}} [[Tommy Robinson (activist)|Tommy Robinson]] founded a subsidiary branch of Pegida in the United Kingdom.Allchorn, William. "Cut from the same cloth?: Pegida UK looks like a sanitized version of the EDL." British Politics and Policy at LSE (2016). ==Position paper== [[File:Pegida Demonstration in Dresden am 05.01.2015 (16084446507).jpg|thumb|"Putin, hilf uns, rette uns!" (''"Putin, help us, save us!"'') and other slogans on signs and banners]] At the beginning of December 2014, Pegida published an undated and anonymous one-page manifesto of 19 bulleted position statements.{{cite web|url=http://www.menschen-in-dresden.de/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/pegida-positionspapier.pdf|title=Pegida Positionspapier|language=German|author=Anonymous|date=10 December 2014|publisher=www.menschen-in-dresden.de}} Pegida's specific demands were initially unclear, largely because Pegida has refused a dialogue, considering the press to be a politically correct conspiracy. Demonstrators have been observed chanting "[[Lügenpresse]]" (lying press) a term that has a long history in German politics.{{cite news |date=24 February 2016 |title=Lying Press? Germans Lose Faith in the Fourth Estate |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/germany/most-germans-think-the-press-is-lying-to-them-about-refugees-a-1079049.html |newspaper=[[Spiegel Online]] |access-date=5 August 2016}} [[File:Proposed German National Flag 1944.svg|thumb|right|Variant of the "Wirmer flag" proposed in 1944 by anti-Nazi resistance member [[Josef Wirmer]] that is often used by members of the movement.]] Alongside the German national flag, supporters of the movement have often been seen with a variant of the "Wirmer flag", a flag proposed by resistance member [[Josef Wirmer]] in 1944 for use after World War II.{{cite news|title=Hundreds attend anti-immigration rally in wake of Cologne sex attacks|url=https://news.yahoo.com/hundreds-xenophobic-pegida-rally-wake-cologne-sex-attacks-145229904.html|work=Yahoo News|date=9 January 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/pegida-warum-in-dresden-die-kreuz-flagge-weht-a-1045600.html|title=Symbolik bei Demos: Warum bei Pegida die Kreuz-Fahne weht – SPIEGEL ONLINE – Politik|first=SPIEGEL ONLINE, Hamburg|last=Germany|publisher=}}{{refn|group=note|The use of the flag gained particular attention in Norway after confusion due to the flag's close resemblance, especially under certain light conditions, with [[Flag of Norway|Norway's national flag]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dagen.no/Nyheter/pegida/Norsk-lignende-flagg-i-Pegida-demonstrasjoner-160847|title=Norsk-lignende flagg i Pegida-demonstrasjoner|publisher=dagen.no}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nrk.no/urix/nei_-det-er-ikke-det-norske-flagget-1.12614156|title=Nei, det er ikke det norske flagget|publisher=nrk.no}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dagbladet.no/2015/10/12/nyheter/pegida/dresden/utenriks/41466096/|title=10 000 demonstrerte mot islam i Tyskland. Dette er flagget de veiver med|publisher=dagbladet.n}}}} According to a ''[[Deutsche Welle]]'' report from December 2014, Pegida considers [[Islamism]] a [[Misogyny|misogynist]] and violent ideology.{{cite news|last1=Knight |first1=Ben|title=PEGIDA determining political debate in Germany|url=http://www.dw.de/pegida-determining-political-debate-in-germany/a-18124875|accessdate=12 December 2014|publisher=Deutsche Welle|date=15 December 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Honnigfort|first1=Bernhard |title=Pegida veröffentlicht Positionspapier|url=http://www.fr-online.de/pegida/dresden-pegida-veroeffentlicht-positionspapier,29337826,29341662.html|accessdate=16 December 2014|publisher=Frankfurter Rundschau|date=15 December 2014|language=German}} In January 2015 ''[[The Guardian]]'' described Pegida as a [[far-right]] movement, the ''[[New York Times]]'' labelled Pegida as [[anti-immigrant]], and Angela Merkel has repeatedly questioned the motives underlying its anti-immigrant message.{{cite news |first=Kate |last=Connolly |title=Pegida: what does the German far-right movement actually stand for? |newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/shortcuts/2015/jan/06/pegida-what-does-german-far-right-movement-actually-stand-for|date=6 January 2015|accessdate=16 January 2015}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/22/world/europe/pegida-hitler-photo-germany.html?_r=0|author=Melissa Eddy|work=New York Times|title=German Anti-Immigrant Figure Quits Post After Posing as Hitler|date=21 January 2015}} The [[State Authority for the Protection of the Constitution]] (Landesamt für Verfassungsschutz) [[Thüringen]] considers ''Sügida'' to be steered by right-wing nationalists.
