[[Federal Agency for Civic Education]], Pegida is "a mixed group—known figures from the [[National Democratic Party of Germany]], soccer hooligans, but also a sizable number of ordinary citizens". Werner Schiffauer, director of the Migration Council has pointed out that the movement is strongest where people have hardly any experience with foreigners, and among "easterners who never really arrived in the Federal Republic and who now feel they have no voice".{{cite news|title=The uprising of the decent|url=https://www.economist.com/news/europe/21638194-xenophobic-marches-continue-parts-germany-others-stand-up-uprising-decent|accessdate=16 January 2015|work=Economist|date=10 January 2015}} In December, Gordian Meyer-Plath, president of the [[Landesamt für Verfassungsschutz Sachsen|Landesamt für Verfassungsschutz]], said that initial suspicion that Pegida might tie in with the riots staged by [[Hogesa]] earlier in [[Cologne]] were not substantiated, so the movement was not put under official surveillance. He said there were no indications that the organizers were embracing right-wingers. This assessment was contested by the weekly ''[[Die Zeit]]'' who researched the ideological proximity of Pegida organizer Siegfried Däbritz to the [[Europe Defence League|German Defence League]] or the European [[Identitarian movement]].{{cite web|title=Neues aus der Tabuzone|work=[[Die Zeit]]|issue=52|url=http://www.zeit.de/2014/52/pegida-dresden-wutbuerger-nationalismus-afd/seite-2|date=17 December 2014|accessdate=22 January 2015|language=de}} In a [[Der Tagesspiegel|Tagesspiegel]] interview on 19 January Meyer-Plath reaffirmed that the participant spectrum was very diverse and that there was no evidence of radicalisation.{{cite web|title=Sachsen im Fokus der Dschihadisten|first=Frank |last=Jansen|work=[[Der Tagesspiegel]]|url=http://www.tagesspiegel.de/politik/verfassungsschutz-praesident-im-interview-sachsen-im-fokus-der-dschihadisten/11250948.html|date=19 January 2015|accessdate=22 January 2015|language=de}} [[File:PEGIDA Demo DRESDEN 25 Jan 2015 116139864.jpg|thumb|left|Pegida demonstration in Dresden]] [[Dresden University of Technology]] (TU) interviewed 400 Pegida demonstrators on 22 December 2014 and 12 January 2015. According to the poll, the main reasons of their participation were dissatisfaction with the political situation (54 percent), "Islam, Islamism and Islamisation” (23 percent), criticism of the media and the public (20 percent), and reservations regarding asylum seekers and migrants (15 percent). In all, 42 percent had reservations regarding Muslims or Islam, 20 percent were concerned about a 'high rate of crimes' committed by asylum seekers, or feared socio-economic disadvantages.{{cite news|last1=Huber|first1=Joachim |url=http://www.tagesspiegel.de/medien/pegida-und-die-luegenpresse-wort-im-mund-umdrehen/11140250.html|title=Pegida und die "Lügenpresse". "Wort im Mund umdrehen"|accessdate=19 January 2015|agency=[http://www.tagesspiegel.de/ Der Tagesspiegel]|date=18 December 2014}} The author, Vorländer, did not see Pegida as a movement of right-wing extremists, pensioners or the unemployed, but stated that the rallies served as a way to express feelings and resentments against a political and opinion-making elite which have not been publicly articulated before.{{cite news|last1=Federl|first1=Fabian|last2=Meisner|first2=Matthias |url=http://www.tagesspiegel.de/politik/hitler-verkleidung-fluechtlinge-als-viehzeug-die-hintergruende-zum-fall-lutz-bachmann/11252882.html|title=Hitler-Verkleidung, Flüchtlinge als "Viehzeug". Die Hintergründe zum Fall Lutz Bachmann|accessdate=22 January 2015|agency=[http://www.tagesspiegel.de/ Der Tagesspiegel]|date=21 January 2015}} A group of social scientists led by Dieter Rucht from the Social Science Research Centre Berlin ([[Wissenschaftszentrum Berlin für Sozialforschung]], WZB) collected data both by flyer and online survey. Despite a participation rate of only 18 percent in the online survey, it largely had similar results to the survey in Dresden. According to data from the WZB, Pegida was a male-dominated group, participants were mostly employees with a relatively high level of education, they had no confidence in institutions and they sympathized with [[Alternative for Germany|AfD]]. In some cases the participants demonstrated far-right and right-wing extremist attitudes. The conclusion emphasized that Pegida supporters cannot be viewed as 'ordinary citizens', since they articulate group-focused enmity and racism.{{cite news|url=http://www.merkur-online.de/politik/pegida-demonstrationen-dresden-anfuehrer-lutz-bachmann-helfer-4539731.html|title=Pegida: Das sind die Köpfe der Bewegung|agency=[http://www.merkur-online.de/ Merkur Online]|date=12 February 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Hauser|first1=Uli|title=ie Köpfe hinter Pegida. Wutbürger, die nicht reden wollen| url=http://www.stern.de/politik/deutschland/2-die-koepfe-hinter-pegida-wutbuerger-die-nicht-reden-wollen-2160107.html |agency=[http://www.stern.de/ Der Stern]|date=15 December 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Locke|first1=Stefan|url=http://www.faz.net/aktuell/politik/inland/demonstrationen-in-dresden-wer-sind-die-organisatoren-der-pegida-proteste-13325574.html|title=Pegida-Organisatoren. Die im Dunkeln sieht man nicht|agency=[http://www.faz.net/aktuell/politik/ Frankfurter Allgemeine]|date=16 December 2014}} {{As of|January 2016}} on Facebook, the Pegida fan page had about 200,000 supporters.{{cite news|last1=Dobmeier|first1=Steffi|last2=Jacobson|first2=Lenz |url=http://www.zeit.de/gesellschaft/zeitgeschehen/2014-12/pegida-dresden-thesen/komplettansicht|title=Dresden. Die wichtigsten Thesen von Pegida|agency=[http://www.zeit.de/index Die Zeit]|date=9 December 2014}} According to political consultant Martin Fuchs, the fanpage allows the users there to present and more easily spread their ideas, which are not represented in the mainstream media.{{cite news|last1=Meier|first1=Albrecht|last2=Niewendick|first2=Martin |url=http://www.tagesspiegel.de/politik/kundgebung-der-islam-hasser-in-dresden-innenminister-de-maiziere-pegida-ist-eine-unverschaemtheit/11091188.html |title=Kundgebung der Islam-Hasser in Dresden Innenminister de Maizière: "Pegida ist eine Unverschämtheit"|agency=[http://www.tagesspiegel.de/ Der Tagesspiegel] |date=9 December 2014}} In December 2014, representatives of the NPD encouraged people to participate in Pegida rallies,{{cite news|last1=Dieckmann|first1=Christoph|last2=Fuchs |first2=Christian|url=http://www.zeit.de/2014/52/pegida-dresden-wutbuerger-nationalismus-afd|title=Schwerpunkt: Pegida – vereint in Wut und Angst. Neues aus der Tabuzone|agency=[http://www.zeit.de/index Die Zeit]|date=17 December 2014}} as did the German Defence League and the internet blog ''Politically Incorrect'' in an uploaded 'propaganda clip'.{{cite news|last1=Pollmer|first1=Cornelius|last2=Schneider|first2=Jens|last3=Bielicki|first3=Jan|url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/politik/demos-gegen-islamisten-rechts-orientierte-wutbuerger-1.2248894|title=Demos gegen Islamisten. Rechts orientierte Wutbürger|agency=[http://www.sueddeutsche.de/ Süddeutsche Zeitung]|date=3 December 2014}} According to the police, a few hundred "violent hooligans" have been participating in the Dresden rallies since December 2014.{{cite journal|title=Vereinsregister des Amtsgerichts Dresden|volume=Blatt VR 7750}} The journalist Felix Menzel supports Pegida with his new right youth magazine ''Blaue Narzisse''.{{cite news|url=http://www.zeit.de/politik/deutschland/2015-01/pegida-steuern-verein|title=Pegida will Steuerbegünstigung|agency=[http://www.zeit.de/index Die Zeit]|date=10 January 2015}} ==Reactions== ===Counterdemonstrations=== [[File:Wzwz 141222 munich against racism j.jpg|thumbnail|Demonstration against Pegida in Munich, 22 December 2014.]] [[File:Kölner Dom - Abschaltung Beleuchtung als Protest gegen die Kögida-Demo.ogg|thumb|Floodlights of [[Cologne Cathedral]] being switched off in protest against a Pegida march on 5 January 2015.]] [[File:Köln stellt sich quer – nokögida 21. Januar 2015-4289.jpg|thumbnail|Demonstration against Pegida in [[Cologne]] on 21 January 2015. The big banner reads "we stand in the way (of racism)", a popular anti racist slogan in Germany]] Numerous protests against Pegida and affiliated movements in cities across Germany have drawn up to 35,000 demonstrators in Dresden{{cite news|url=http://www.dnn-online.de/dresden/web/dresden-nachrichten/detail/-/specific/35-000-Menschen-bei-Kundgebung-fuer-Weltoffenheit-in-Dresden-3132319785|title=Dresden setzt Zeichen für Weltoffenheit - 35.000 Menschen bei Kundgebung gegen Pegida|date=11 January 2015|work=DNN online|accessdate=12 January 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150113000843/http://www.dnn-online.de/dresden/web/dresden-nachrichten/detail/-/specific/35-000-Menschen-bei-Kundgebung-fuer-Weltoffenheit-in-Dresden-3132319785#|archive-date=13 January 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-30765674 |title=BBC News Germany protests: Dresden marches against anti-Islamists Pegida |date=10 January 2015 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=12 January 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150111154808/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-30765674 |archivedate=11 January 2015 }} and up to 100,000 nationwide in January 2015, considerably more than Pegida's own concurrent demonstrations.{{cite news|url=http://www.faz.net/aktuell/politik/kundgebungen-in-vielen-staedten-deutschlandweit-proteste-gegen-islamfeinde-13366521.html|title=Deutschlandweit Proteste gegen Islamfeinde|date=12 January 2015|work=Frankfurter Allgemeine|accessdate=12 January 2015}} In protest against a Pegida march, the floodlights of the Catholic [[Cologne Cathedral]] were switched off on the evening of 5 January 2015.{{cite news|title=Cologne Cathedral to turn out the lights in protest at anti-Muslim march|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/01/02/us-germany-immigration-idUSKBN0KB0KU20150102|accessdate=3 January 2015|work=Reuters|date=2 January 2015}} Dresden's [[Volkswagen]] plant used the same method of protest.{{cite news|title=Germany Pegida protests: 'Islamisation' rallies denounced|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-30694406|accessdate=6 January 2015|work=BBC News|date=6 January 2015}} German tabloid newspaper ''[[Bild]]'' launched a petition against Pegida, including former Chancellors [[Helmut Schmidt]] and [[Gerhard Schröder]], as well as actress [[Karoline Herfurth]] and former footballer [[Oliver Bierhoff]]. ===Polls=== According to a [[Opinion poll|survey]] by the Emnid institute conducted in December 2014, 53% of East Germans and 48% of West Germans showed understanding for Pegida demonstrations. Differentiated by political parties, supporters consisted of 86% of all surveyed [[Alternative for Germany|AfD]] members, 54% of all [[Christian Democratic Union of Germany|CDU]] members, 46% of all [[Social Democratic Party of Germany|SPD]] members and 19% of all questioned supporters of [[The Left (Germany)|Die Linke]] and [[Alliance '90/The Greens|Die Grünen]] respectively.{{cite news|title=Anti-Islam-Bewegung "Pegida": Mehrheit der Ostdeutschen zeigt Verständnis.|url=http://www.n24.de/n24/Nachrichten/Politik/d/5860796/mehrheit-der-ostdeutschen-zeigt-verstaendnis.html|accessdate=11 February 2015|work=n24|date=14 December 2014}} 43% of all Germans participating in the survey thought that Pegida protesters are mainly concerned about the "spread of Islam“. 33% believed that mainly [[Right-wing politics|right wing]] extremists attend their demonstrations.{{cite news|title=Deutsche vermuten Neonazis und besorgte Bürger hinter PEGIDA.|url=http://www.presseportal.de/pm/13399/2903923/n24-emnid-umfrage-zu-pegida-und-asyl-deutsche-vermuten-neonazis-und-besorgte-buerger-hinter-pegida|accessdate=11 February 2015|work=Presseportal|date=11 December 2014}} On behalf of German online newspaper Zeit Online, [[YouGov]] conducted a survey from 12 to 15 December 2014. The survey showed that 30% of all 1107 surveyed felt sympathetic with regards to the demonstrations. Another 19% said they were understanding rather than the opposite. 26% approved at least partially of the demonstrations, while 10% showed little sympathy and a further 13% no understanding at all.{{cite news|title=Anti-Islam-Proteste: Jeder Zweite sympathisiert mit Pegida.|url=http://www.zeit.de/politik/deutschland/2014-12/islam-pegida-fluechtlinge-deutschland-umfrage|accessdate=11 February 2015|work=Die Zeit|date=15 December 2014}} A survey by TNS Infratest conducted in December 2014 on behalf of German magazine ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' showed that 65% of all surveyed German citizens felt that the government did not respond appropriately to their concerns about asylum [[Public policy|policy]] and immigration. 28% disagreed, while 34% observed an increasing Islamisation in Germany.{{cite news|title=Spiegel-Umfrage zur Flüchtlingspolitik: Deutsche fühlen sich von Regierung übergangen.|url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/deutsche-kritisieren-fluechtlingspolitik-ein-drittel-stimmt-pegida-zu-a-1008274.html|accessdate=11 February 2015|work=Der Spiegel|date=13 December 2014}} A representative survey by Emnid conducted from 17 to 18 December 2014 showed that 85% of all 1006 surveyed were not willing to participate in demonstrations for Pegida policy. Only 9%, more than half of all surveyed AfD followers, said they were in fact willing to demonstrate.{{cite news|title=Protest gegen angebliche Islamisierung – So viele Deutsche würden bei Pegida mitmarschieren.|url=http://www.focus.de/politik/deutschland/protest-gegen-angebliche-islamisierung-umfrage-so-viele-deutsche-wuerden-mit-pegida-demonstrieren_id_4360367.html|accessdate=11 February 2015|work=Focus|date=20 December 2014}} On 18 December 2014, the [[Forsa Institute]] conducted a survey which showed that 67% of all surveyed Germans considered the danger of Islamisation exaggerated. 29%, consisting of 71% of all surveyed AfD supporters, felt too strong an Islamic influence in Germany and deemed respective demonstrations justified. 13% said they would participate in protests near their residence. 10%, consisting of 57% of all surveyed AfD followers, would even vote for an [[Criticism of Islam|anti-Islamic]] party.{{cite news|last=Mathes|first=Werner|title=stern-Umfrage: 13 Prozent der Deutschen würden für Pegida marschieren.|url=http://www.stern.de/politik/deutschland/fuer-pegida-auf-die-strasse-13-prozent-der-deutschen-wuerden-mitmarschieren-2163092.html|accessdate=11 February 2015|work=Stern|date=1 January 2015}} A special report by the [[Bertelsmann Foundation]], complemented by a TNS Emnid survey from November 2014, showed that a majority of German citizens considered Islam dangerous. Consequently, there seemed to be a "strong sympathy“ for „Pegida paroles“. In absolute numbers, 57% of all surveyed thought of Islam as a danger. 40% felt like "foreigners in their own country“, while 24% stated that they would like to prevent further Muslim immigration. These opinions were not exclusive to any political camps or [[social class]]es.{{cite news|last=Löbbert|first=Raoul|title=Religionsmonitor: 57 Prozent der Deutschen fühlen sich vom Islam bedroht.|url=http://www.zeit.de/gesellschaft/zeitgeschehen/2015-01/islam-pegida-islamfeindlichkeit-religionsmonitor|accessdate=11 February 2015|work=Zeit Online|date=8 January 2015}} ===Political opponents=== Chancellor [[Angela Merkel]] has criticized Pegida, saying that the leaders of Pegida "have prejudice, coldness, even hatred in their hearts”.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/dec/30/angela-merkel-criticizes-pegida-far-right-group-germany|title=Angela Merkel issues New Year’s warning over rightwing Pegida group|date=30 December 2014|work=The Guardian|accessdate=2 January 2015}} The [[Federal Ministry of the Interior (Germany)|Federal Minister of the Interior]] [[Thomas de Maizière]] said that among the participants of the mass rallies were many ordinary people who expressed their concerns about the challenges of today's society.{{cite news|last1=vek|first1=dpa|title= Protest-Märsche: De Maizière zeigt Verständnis für Pegida-Demonstranten|url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/pegida-proteste-thomas-de-maiziere-zeigt-verstaendnis-a-1008028.html|accessdate=16 December 2014|publisher=SPIEGEL Online|date=12 December 2014}} [[Bernd Lucke]], the leader of the political party [[Alliance for Progress and Renewal]], has said he considers most of the positions of Pegida to be legitimate.{{cite news|last1=Hill|first1=Jenny|title=Anti-Islam 'Pegida' march in German city of Dresden|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-30478321|accessdate=16 December 2014|publisher=BBC|date=16 December 2014}} According to Lucke, the people taking part in these demonstrations did not feel that their concerns were being understood by politicians.{{cite news|last1=Hugglet|first1=Justin|title=German Eurosceptics embrace anti-Islam protests|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/germany/11285422/German-Eurosceptics-embrace-anti-Islam-protests.html|accessdate=16 December 2014|publisher=The Telegraph|date=10 December 2014}} Similarly, the Dresden city council's AfD faction welcomed Pegida's weekly demonstrations.{{cite web|author1=AfD-Fraktion, Dresden|title=Erklärung der AfD-Fraktion im Stadtrat der Landeshauptstadt Dresden zu den Demonstrationen von PEGIDA|url=http://www.afd-fraktion-dresden.de/nachrichtenleser/afd-fraktion-zu-pegida.html|publisher=AfD|accessdate=5 January 2015|language=German|date=20 November 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150105141722/http://www.afd-fraktion-dresden.de/nachrichtenleser/afd-fraktion-zu-pegida.html|archivedate=5 January 2015|df=dmy-all}} [[Josef Schuster]], chairman of the [[Central Council of Jews in Germany]], voiced his opposition to the group, saying that the possibility of an Islamic conquest of Germany would be as "absurd" as a [[Fourth Reich|resurrection of the Nazi regime]]. Schuster described Pegida as being "highly dangerous": “It starts with verbal assault and leads to actual attacks like the one on a planned refugee hostel in Bavaria". He referred to an arson attack on a home for asylum-seekers that was ready for occupation. After the attack, swastika graffiti was found at the scene. Schuster said that Pegida is a combination of "neo-Nazis, far-right parties and citizens who think they are finally allowed to show their racism and xenophobia openly". He condemned the movement, stating that the fear of Islamist terror was being exploited to disparage an entire religion.{{cite news|title=German Council of Jews chairman condemns "immensely dangerous" PEGIDA movement|url=http://www.dw.de/german-council-of-jews-chairman-condemns-immensely-dangerous-pegida-movement/a-18143163|accessdate=22 December 2014|work=[[Deutsche Welle]]|date=20 December 2014}} Aiman Mazyek from the [[Central Council of Muslims in Germany]] stated that again and again right-wing extremists gave the public the false impression of a racist Germany. The slogans of the protesters showed that xenophobia and anti-Semitic racism had become socially acceptable.{{contradict-inline|date=February 2015}}{{citation needed|date=February 2015}} Pegida has been criticized by Lutheran clergy, including the [[Bishop of Hamburg]] Kirsten Fehrs.{{cite news|title=Bischof will ehrlichen Dialog mit Muslimen über IS|trans-title=Bishop wants honest dialogue with Muslims on IS|url=https://www.welt.de/politik/deutschland/article135728231/Bischof-will-ehrlichen-Dialog-mit-Muslimen-ueber-IS.html|accessdate=28 December 2014|work=[[Die Welt]]|date=24 December 2014|language=German}} Bachmann's credibility as a leader has been criticized because he has numerous criminal convictions, including "16 burglaries, drink-driving or without a licence and even dealing in cocaine". In 1998 he fled to South Africa to avoid German justice, but was finally extradited and served his two-year jail sentence.{{Cite news |title=German xenophobia: Peaceful, but menacing |newspaper=The Economist |date=20 December 2014 |url=https://www.economist.com/news/europe/21636765-new-movement-barely-hidden-message-hate-unsettles-germany-peaceful-menacing}} In November 2014, [[Saxony]]'s Interior Minister, [[Markus Ulbig]] (CDU), claimed that foreign criminals stayed in Germany too long. He announced the creation of a special police unit to deal with criminal immigrants in [[Dresden]] and the rest of Saxony. Investigators and specialists in criminal and immigrant law would collaborate to process foreign criminals in the criminal justice system, and prevent those not eligible for asylum from obtaining the right to stay in Germany.{{cite news|url= http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/asylbewerber-sachsen-plant-sondereinheit-der-polizei-a-1004670.html |title= Pläne in Sachsen: Sondereinheit soll gegen straffällige Asylbewerber "durchgreifen" |publisher=[[Der Spiegel]] |date= 24 November 2014 |accessdate= 9 January 2015 |trans-title= Plans in Saxony: Special unit to clamp down on criminal asylum seekers |language=German}} Ulbig admitted that there had been a number of criminal acts committed by immigrants near the homes for [[Right of asylum|asylum]]-seekers, but these were a minority and should not be allowed to undermine solidarity with the great majority of law-abiding refugees. He said police worked on criminal immigrant cases too slowly.{{cite news|author1=Robert Kuhne|title=Innenminister Ulbig zur Asylpolitik|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wo2H71n4qA8|work=MOPO24|date=24 November 2014|language=German}} {{anchor|Bärgida|Kögida}} On the night of 5 January 2015, the lights illuminating the [[Brandenburg Gate]] were completely turned off in protest against the Berlin offshoot named "Bärgida"[[Tagesspiegel]]: [http://www.tagesspiegel.de/berlin/polizei-justiz/berliner-pegida-protestiert-in-mitte-baergida-und-gegendemonstrationen-beendet/11186364.html Bärgida und Gegendemonstration beendet (in German)], 5 January 2015, retrieved 20 November 2015[[Rundfunk Berlin-Brandenburg|RBB]]: [http://www.rbb-online.de/politik/beitrag/2015/01/bergida-pegida-berlin-brandenburger-tor-gegendemo.html Licht aus am Brandenburger Tor (in German)]{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=Dr.K. |fix-attempted=yes }} "Lights off at Brandenburg Gate", 5 January 2015, retrieved 20 November 2015 and also the lights of the Catholic cathedral [[Kölner Dom]] in Cologne in repudiation against "Kögida".Storify: [https://storify.com/reportedly/anti-islamization-rally-in-germany-met-with-countr Anti-islamisation rally in Germany met with countrywide protests], 5 January 2015, retrieved 20 November 2015 The exterior lighting of the [[Semperoper]] in Dresden was also kept dark during the weekly Pegida marches. Both rallies in Berlin and Cologne were successfully blocked and disbanded by counterdemonstrations.[[Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung|FAZ]]: [http://www.faz.net/aktuell/politik/inland/bundesweite-aktionen-licht-aus-gegen-pegida-13354421.html#aufmacherOverlay Licht aus gegen Pegida (in German)], "Lights off against Pegida", 5 January 2015, retrieved 20 November 2015 On 26 January 2015 the US [[Overseas Security Advisory Council]] published an online security message entitled "Demonstration Notice Riots/Civil Unrest", stating U.S. citizens in Berlin, Frankfurt and Munich may "encounter Pegida and counter-Pegida demonstrations" on 26 January and 16 February 2015 in Düsseldorf, and "should avoid areas of demonstrations".{{cite web|author1=Overseas Security Advisory Council - Bureau of Diplomatic Security|title=Security Message for U.S. Citizens: Berlin (Germany), Demonstration Notice |url=https://www.osac.gov/Pages/ContentReportDetails.aspx?cid=16965|publisher=U.S. Department of State|accessdate=1 February 2015|date=26 January 2015}} ===Reactions from political scientists=== [[Political science|Political scientist]] Werner J. Patzelt{{cite web |url=http://tu-dresden.de/die_tu_dresden/fakultaeten/philosophische_fakultaet/ifpw/polsys/mitarbeiter/lehrstuhlinhaber |title=TUD - Philosophische Fakultät - Lehrstuhlinhaber |publisher=Tu-dresden.de |date=19 January 2015 |accessdate=17 February 2015 |language=de |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150108102817/http://tu-dresden.de/die_tu_dresden/fakultaeten/philosophische_fakultaet/ifpw/polsys/mitarbeiter/lehrstuhlinhaber# |archive-date=8 January 2015 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} from Dresden believes that politicians are 'clueless' when it comes to dealing with Pegida. He says that this points to a serious problem in [[society]], which neither the [[Left-wing politics|left wing]] nor parties of the [[Centrism|political middle ground]] concern themselves with. This allows new social initiatives critical of Islam and immigrants to form.{{cite news|last=Hach|first=Oliver|title=Pegida - oder: Die Welle.|url=http://www.freiepresse.de/NACHRICHTEN/SACHSEN/Pegida-oder-Die-Welle-artikel9048569.php|accessdate=11 February 2015|work=FreiePresse|date=28 November 2014}} According to him, the demonstrators are normal people approachable by the [[Christian Democratic Union (Germany)|CDU]], if only the party stopped following [[ostrich policy]] concerning immigration.{{cite news|title=Des "patriotes" allemands se mobilizent contre l’immigration.|url=http://www.letemps.ch/Page/Uuid/1042927e-80ae-11e4-9a92-1e037d8e04b7/Des_patriotes_allemands_se_mobilizent_contre_limmigration|accessdate=11 February 2015|work=Le Temps|date=11 December 2014}} [[Far-right politics]] expert Hans-Gerd Jaschke thinks that the demands in Pegida’s position paper stem from the [[middle class]] [[Centre-right politics|centre-right]] and could as well be the content of [[CDU/CSU]]’s position papers.{{cite web|url=http://www.dw.de/jaschke-jetzt-ist-die-zivilgesellschaft-gefragt/a-18125144 |title=Jaschke: "Jetzt ist die Zivilgesellschaft gefragt" | Deutschland | DW.DE | 12.12.2014 |publisher=DW.DE |date=13 December 2014 |accessdate=17 February 2015}} Social psychologist [[Andreas Zick]] from the Institute for Interdisciplinary Research on Conflict and Violence (IKG) assesses the party as a “middle-class right-wing populist movement”.{{cite news|last=Pabst|first=Sabrina|title=Jaschke: Jetzt ist die Zivilgesellschaft gefragt.|url=http://www.dw.de/jaschke-jetzt-ist-die-zivilgesellschaft-gefragt/a-18125144|accessdate=11 February 2015|work=Deutsche Welle|date=12 December 2014}} According to right-wing extremism researcher Johannes Kies, Pegida states what many people think.{{cite news|last=Lachmann|first=Harald|title=Dresden und der Pegida-Protest: Sorge um die weltoffene Stadt.|url=http://www.stuttgarter-zeitung.de/inhalt.dresden-und-der-pegida-protest-sorge-um-die-weltoffene-stadt.27d42051-6d58-427b-b801-a29fa58de02e.html|accessdate=11 February 2015|work=Stuttgarter Zeitung|date=8 December 2014}} Kies says that these opinions are widespread in society and that great anti-democratic potential is erupting there.{{cite news|last=Bohmann|first=Christin|title=Extremismus-Forscher: "Pegida spricht aus, was die Leute denken."|url=http://www.mdr.de/nachrichten/pegida-interview-extremismusforscher100.html|accessdate=11 February 2015|work=MDR|date=1 December 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150219033820/http://www.mdr.de/nachrichten/pegida-interview-extremismusforscher100.html#|archive-date=19 February 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} According to political scientist Alexander Häusler we are facing “a right-wing oriented group of enraged citizens”, that “mingles with members of the right-wing scene and even hooligans”.{{cite news|last=Gensing|first=Patrick|title=Pegida- und HoGeSa-Demonstrationen: Gegen Islamismus, für 'Heimatschutz'|url=https://www.tagesschau.de/inland/pegida-103.html|accessdate=11 February 2015|work=tagesschau|date=1 December 2014}} Political scientist Hajo Funke sees a connection between Pegida and the great increase in attacks on asylum seekers in 2014. He says that because politics did not react to the population’s fear of ever-increasing numbers of asylum seekers, these groups could use these fears and fan them further.{{cite news|last=Kandzora|first=Jan|title=Proteste gegen Asyl und Islam: Das steckt hinter Pegida und Bagida.|url=http://www.augsburger-allgemeine.de/politik/Proteste-gegen-Asyl-und-Islam-Das-steckt-hinter-Pegida-und-Bagida-id32271632.html|accessdate=11 February 2015|work=Augsburger Allgemeine|date=8 December 2014}} In his article for the German newspaper [[Die Zeit|Zeit Online]], political scientist and historian Michael Lühmann called it “cynical to want to place Pegida in the [[Monday demonstrations in East Germany|tradition of 1989]]”. The demonstrators in Dresden do not align themselves with the philosophy of the extreme right-wing, he says, but they fit the bill for “extremism of the centre ground”, which is widespread in Saxony and for whose “group-based misanthropy […] at times the CDU, but prevalently the [[National Democratic Party of Germany|NPD]] and as of now the [[Alternative for Germany|AfD]] stand” in parliament.{{cite news|last=Lühmann|first=Michael|title=Dresden: Pegida passt nach Sachsen.|url=http://www.zeit.de/politik/deutschland/2014-12/pegida-dresden-politische-tradition|accessdate=11 February 2015|work=Zeit Online|date=16 December 2014}} In a similar fashion, historian [[Götz Aly]] traces the fact that Pegida were able to form in Dresden back to the city’s history. In one of his columns in the [[Berliner Zeitung]] he referred to the [[Jewish emancipation]] of 19th century Saxony, where the comparatively few resident [[Jews]] were faced with unequally difficult legal obstacles. Aly concluded that in Dresden “[[freedom]], self-aggrandising local presumption and [[fear]] of foreigners” have long belonged together.{{cite news|last=Aly|first=Götz|title=Pegida, eine alte Dresdner Eigenheit.|url=http://www.berliner-zeitung.de/meinung/kolumne-zur-fremdenangst-in-dresden-pegida--eine-alte-dresdner-eigenheit,10808020,29338774.html|accessdate=11 February 2015|work=Berliner Zeitung|date=15 December 2014}} Political philosopher Jürgen Manemann considers Pegida an anti-political movement. According to Manemann, political action serves the [[common good]] and thus requires politicians to voice especially the interests of minorities. While politics was based on [[Pluralism (political philosophy)|pluralism]], Pegida was in fact anti-pluralistic and thus anti-political. In Manemann’s eyes, the movement has neither an appreciation of [[Alterity|otherness]] nor [[empathy]], which he sees as the basic virtue of political action.{{cite news|last=Manemann|first=Jürgen|title=InDebate: Pegida ist eine anti-politische Bewegung!|url=http://philosophie-indebate.de/2052/indebate-pegida-ist-eine-anti-politische-bewegung|accessdate=11 February 2015|work=Philosophie Indebate|date=22 December 2014}} Explaining especially those protests against the actually non-existent threat of Islamisation from people with middle-class backgrounds, political scientist [[Gesine Schwan]] referred to results from studies on [[prejudice]]. These studies indicate that aggressive prejudices do not originate from those groups met with [[resentment]], but are rather a result of the situation of those who have them. In addition, fear of social decline often seems to be expressed through [[aggression]]. This is then directed especially against those minorities which may seem dangerous, but are in reality unable to defend themselves, often due to a perceived unpopularity within the respective society. In the first half of the 20th century, it was the Jewish minority who were imputed with plans for [[world domination]]. Today, it is the Muslim minority who is accused of plotting an Islamisation of Europe.{{cite news|last=Schwan|first=Gesine|title=Fremdenhass: Pegida ist überall.|url=http://www.zeit.de/2015/01/pegida-abstiegsangst-weimarer-republik|accessdate=11 February 2015|work=Zeit Online|date=30 December 2014}} In an interview about Pegida, researcher on prejudice [[Wolfgang Benz]] referred to his previous warnings about right-wing extremists using the fear of foreign infiltration for their ends. It was not the formation but the attendance figures that really surprised him.{{cite news|last=Cordsen|first=Knut|title=Patriotismus oder Vorurteile? Historiker Wolfgang Benz über die Pegida-Proteste.|url=http://www.br.de/radio/bayern2/kultur/kulturwelt/gespraech-mit-wolfgang-benz-pegida-100.html|accessdate=11 February 2015|work=BR|date=17 December 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150120085032/http://www.br.de/radio/bayern2/kultur/kulturwelt/gespraech-mit-wolfgang-benz-pegida-100.html|archivedate=20 January 2015|df=dmy-all}} Political scientist and researcher on extremism Armin Pfahl-Traughber considers Pegida demonstrations "a new phenomenon of [[xenophobia]]".{{cite news|last=Cordsen|first=Knut|title=Die Pegida-Demonstrationen als neues Phänomen für Fremdenfeindlichkeit.|url=http://www.endstation-rechts.de/news/kategorie/sonstige/artikel/die-pegida-demonstrationen-als-neues-phaenomen-fuer-fremdenfeindlichkeit.html|accessdate=11 February 2015|work=Endstation Rechts|date=5 January 2015}} In an interview, he accused Pegida leaders of fuelling "[[hostility]] and [[hatred]] against people of different [[Ethnic group|ethnicity]] or religion".{{cite news|last=Kurz|first=Peter|title=Politologe Pfahl-Traughber zu Pegida: "Bevormundung der Basis."|url=http://www.wz-newsline.de/home/politik/inland/politologe-pfahl-traughber-zu-pegida-bevormundung-der-basis-1.1828279|accessdate=11 February 2015|work=Westdeutsche Zeitung|date=2 January 2014}} On 5 January 2015, the Council on Migration{{cite web|url=http://www.rat-fuer-migration.de/ |title=Rat für Migration |publisher=Rat-fuer-migration.de |date= |accessdate=17 February 2015}} called for a new general orientation in German society. Since, in their eyes, migration was controllable only to a limited extent, they suggested an orientation committee. Consisting of politicians and representatives of immigrants and minorities, this would work together in order to analyse and redefine "German [[National identity|identity]] and [[solidarity]] in a pluralist [[Republicanism|republican]] society". Their results were to be included in German schools' curricula in order to emphasize the historical importance of [[Immigration to Germany|migration in Germany]]. In the eyes of the Council, German policy has been influenced for far too long by the CDU's guiding principle of "Germany not being a land of immigration". Thus, a concept of integration should include foreigners and refugees in German society. According to the Council, German integration policy should not only focus on immigrants, but also provide courses on integration for groups such as Pegida. Praising German Chancellor Angela Merkel's distancing herself from Pegida, the Council stressed that an immigration society is a very complex construct.{{cite news|last=Reimann|first=Anna|title=Umgang mit Pegida: Forscher fordern neues Deutschland-Bild in Lehrplänen.|url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/pegida-migrationsforscher-fordern-neues-leitbild-fuer-deutschland-a-1011260.html|accessdate=11 February 2015|work=Spiegel Online|date=5 January 2014}} Political theorist Wolfgang Jäger considers Pegida a part of increasingly right-wing populist tendencies in Europe, in their Islamophobia possibly being the heir to widespread [[antisemitism]]. He claims that the demonstrations themselves expose the movement's moderate position paper as a [[fig leaf]] for "blatantly unconstitutional xenophobia". Thus, democrats should not sympathize with the movement, as their referring in particular to Judeo-Christian values was contrary to their actual demands. Jäger also voiced concerns about the "ghosts of the old [[German nationalism|nationalism]] re-entering Germany through the back door". According to political theorists, a democracy needs to be measured by how it [[Minority rights|protects its minorities]]. A knowledge of foreign cultures should be taught in schools. Only in this way would it be possible to understand [[globalisation]] as a chance for cultural enrichment in the face of global [[terrorism]].{{cite news|last=Jäger|first=Wolfgang|title=Die Gespenster des völkischen Nationalismus.|url=http://www.badische-zeitung.de/meinung/kommentare/die-gespenster-des-voelkischen-nationalismus|accessdate=11 February 2015|work=Badische Zeitung|date=10 January 2014}} ===International reactions=== The controversy around Pegida sparked reactions from international media as well. In France, ''[[Le Monde]]'' wrote that Islamophobia divided German society, while ''[[Libération]]'' and ''[[L'Opinion]]'' discussed possible parallels to the French far-right [[National Front (France)|Front National]].{{cite web|title=Ist Pegida ein deutscher Front National?|url=http://www.faz.net/aktuell/politik/ausland/frankreichs-reaktion-ist-pegida-ein-deutscher-front-national-13356464.html|website=Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung|accessdate=12 February 2015}} Several French and francophone cartoonists published a flyer aimed against a funeral march by Pegida in the wake of the [[Charlie Hebdo shooting|''Charlie Hebdo'' shooting]] in January 2015. The signatories - among them a surviving member of ''[[Charlie Hebdo]]'''s editorial staff – disapproved of Pegida using the mourning to gather attention for their own cause. They stated that Pegida symbolized everything ''Charlie Hebdo'' had fought against and asked the population of Dresden for more tolerance and to be open towards different cultures.{{cite web|title=Französische Karikaturisten wehren sich gegen Pegida|url=http://www.zeit.de/politik/ausland/2015-01/frankreich-charlie-hebdo-karrikaturen-pegida-paris-dresden|website=Die Zeit|accessdate=12 February 2015}} ''[[The Times]]'' claimed that, for the first time since 1945, a German populist movement was publicly complaining about an ethnic minority. This would frighten the establishment. [[BBC News]] said that Germany is not used to such large numbers of demonstrators supporting such positions.{{cite web|title=Das moderne Deutschland ist das nicht gewohnt|url=http://www.zeit.de/gesellschaft/zeitgeschehen/2015-01/pegida-internationale-presse|website=Die Zeit|accessdate=12 February 2015}} ''[[The Guardian]]'' described Pegida as an emerging campaign against immigrants that would eventually endanger tourism.{{cite web|title=Ausländische Medien über Pegida: "Im Tal der Ahnungslosen"|url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/pegida-und-dresden-wie-die-auslaendische-presse-die-bewegung-sieht-a-1008750.html|website=Der Spiegel|accessdate=12 February 2015}} ''[[The New York Times]]'' claimed that, because of its communist history, East Germany was more xenophobic than the rest of the country. The paper claimed that, in light of the low numbers of Muslims living in Saxony, the fear of Islamisation was bizarre.{{cite news|title=In German City Rich With History and Tragedy, Tide Rises Against Immigration|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/08/world/in-german-city-rich-with-history-and-tragedy-tide-rises-against-immigration.html?_r=0|website=International New York Times|accessdate=12 February 2015}} [[Russia Today]] reported comprehensively on Pegida. Its subsidiary [[Ruptly]] broadcast several rallies live on the internet.{{cite web|title=Weltpresse über deutsche Islamfeinde: "Die Rhetorik von Pegida ist armselig"|url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/pegida-das-sagt-die-internationale-presse-zu-den-protesten-a-1011431.html|website=Der Spiegel|accessdate=12 February 2015}} Turkey's ''[[Hürriyet]]'' and [[Sabah (newspaper)|''Sabah'']] reported on Pegida and counterrallies. Sabah interpreted the demonstrations as a “rise of the radical right in Europe”. In an interview with the ''[[Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung]]'', Turkish prime minister [[Ahmet Davutoğlu]] compared Pegida followers with members of the terror organisation IS. He said that both had an archaic mindset and that Turkey was "very concerned about Pegida". He called the movement a “threat to Turks, Muslims and Germany itself”.{{cite web|title=Türkischer Regierungschef vergleicht Pegida mit IS|url=http://www.faz.net/aktuell/politik/inland/tuerkeis-regierungschef-davutoglu-vergleicht-pegida-mit-is-13367895.html|website=Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung|accessdate=12 February 2015}} The Arabic news network [[Al Jazeera]] primarily reported on counter-demonstrations. ==Offshoots and variations== ===In Germany=== Pegida has spawned a number of smaller offshoots across Germany, including ''Legida'' in [[Leipzig]], ''Sügida'' in [[Thüringen|Südthüringen]], ''Kagida'' in [[Kassel]], ''Wügida'' in [[Würzburg]], ''Bogida'' in [[Bonn]], ''Dügida'' in [[Düsseldorf]], and ''Fragida'' in [[Frankfurt]].{{cite news|last=Gedziorowski |first=Lukas|title=Pegida wird Fragida|url=http://www.journal-frankfurt.de/journal_news/Politik-10/Anti-Islamisierungsbewegung-kommt-nach-Frankfurt-Pegida-wird-Fragida-23358.html|accessdate=16 December 2014|publisher=Journal Frankfurt|date=15 December 2014|language=de}} After some internal disputes, representatives of ''Pegida NRW'', an affiliate aiming to operate in the federal state of [[North Rhine Westphalia]], distanced itself from the ''Bogida'', ''Dügida'' and ''Kögida'' clones in North Rhine Westphalia. The latter were said to have been taken over by members of the openly xenophobic right-wing splinter party [[Pro NRW]].{{cite web|url=http://www.faz.net/aktuell/politik/inland/dresdens-pegida-buendnis-distanziert-sich-von-nrw-ablegern-13364370.html|first=Reiner|last=Burger|title=Schwarze Pädagogik, die wir nicht nötig haben|work=[[Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung]]|date=12 January 2015|accessdate=17 January 2015|language=de}} In January 2015, ''Pegida NRW'' replaced their media representative Melanie Dittmer with Sebastian Nobile, a member of the ''German Defence League'', an anti-Islamist organisation modelled on the [[English Defence League]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ksta.de/politik/nach-scheitern-von-koegida-pegida-nrw-feuert-pressesprecherin-und-will-koeln-kuenftig-meiden,15187246,29492340.html|title=Pegida-NRW feuert Pressesprecherin und will Köln künftig meiden|work=[[Kölner Stadt-Anzeiger]]|date=6 January 2015|accessdate=17 January 2015|language=de}} In December 2014, rival right-wing forces founded an [[anti-Americanism|anti-American]] Facebook group under the name PEGADA ({{lang-de|Patriotische Europäer gegen die Amerikanisierung des Abendlandes}}, or "Patriotic Europeans Against the Americanisation of the West"), claiming the true problem was not the phenomenon of Islamism but the suspected American forces behind it. On 25 January they held a first rally in Erfurt under the title ''EnDgAmE'' ({{lang|de|Engagierte Demokraten gegen die Amerikanisierung Europas}}, or "Committed democrats against the Americanisation of Europe"). {{cleanup rewrite|reason=Even articles on pseudoscience should have standards|date=March 2018}} The '''cataclysmic pole shift''' [[fringe theory]] suggests that there have been geologically rapid shifts in the relative positions of the modern-day geographic locations of the poles and the [[axis of rotation]] of the [[Earth]], creating calamities such as floods and tectonic events.<ref>{{cite book |first = Patrick J. |last = Kiger |title = Ends of the Earth: Shifting of the Poles |work = [[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]] |url = http://channel.nationalgeographic.com/channel/ends-of-the-earth-pole-shift-2 |accessdate = 2009-11-22 |deadurl = bot: unknown |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130322081112/http://channel.nationalgeographic.com/channel/ends-of-the-earth-pole-shift-2 |archivedate = 2013-03-22 |df = }}</ref>
There is evidence of [[precession]] and changes in [[axial tilt]], but this change is on much longer time-scales and does not involve relative motion of the spin axis with respect to the planet. However, in what is known as [[true polar wander]], the solid Earth can rotate with respect to a fixed spin axis. Research shows that during the last 200 million years a total true polar wander of some 30° has occurred, but that no super-rapid shifts in the Earth's pole were found during this period.<ref name=jgr107_b11/> A characteristic rate of true polar wander is 1° or less per million years.<ref name="jgr90" /> Between approximately 790 and 810 million years ago, when the [[supercontinent]] [[Rodinia]] existed, two geologically rapid phases of true polar wander may have occurred. In each of these, the magnetic poles of the Earth shifted by approximately 55°.<ref name="gsab118">{{cite journal | author=Maloof, Adam C. | url=http://gsabulletin.gsapubs.org/content/118/9-10/1099.abstract | title=Combined paleomagnetic, isotopic, and stratigraphic evidence for true polar wander from the Neoproterozoic Akademikerbreen Group, Svalbard, Norway | journal=[[Geological Society of America Bulletin]] | volume=118 | issue=9 | pages=1099–1124 | year=2006 | doi=10.1130/B25892.1 | display-authors=1 | last2=Halverson | first2=G. P. | last3=Kirschvink | first3=J. L. | last4=Schrag | first4=D. P. | last5=Weiss | first5=B. P. | last6=Hoffman | first6=P. F. |bibcode = 2006GSAB..118.1099M }}</ref>
== Definition and clarification ==
The [[geographic pole]]s are defined by the points on the surface of the Earth that are intersected by the axis of rotation. The pole shift hypothesis describes a change in location of these poles with respect to the underlying surface – a phenomenon distinct from the changes in axial orientation with respect to the [[plane of the ecliptic]] that are caused by [[precession]] and [[nutation]], and is an amplified event of a [[true polar wander]].
Pole shift hypotheses are not connected with [[plate tectonics]], the well-accepted geological theory that the Earth's surface consists of solid plates which shift over a viscous, or semifluid [[asthenosphere]]; nor with [[continental drift]], the corollary to plate tectonics which maintains that locations of the continents have moved slowly over the face of the Earth,<ref>{{cite web | first=C. R. | last=Scotese | authorlink = Christopher Scotese| title=The PaleoMap Project | url=http://www.scotese.com/earth.htm | accessdate=2010-05-04 }}</ref> resulting in the gradual emerging and breakup of continents and oceans over hundreds of millions of years.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Cottrell, R. D. |author2=Tarduno, J. A. | title=Late Cretaceous True Polar Wander: Not So Fast | journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]] | date=June 30, 2000 | volume=288 | issue=5475 | page=2283 | doi=10.1126/science.288.5475.2283a | accessdate=2010-05-04 | url=http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/full/288/5475/2283a | pmid=17769831}}</ref>
Pole shift hypotheses are not the same as [[geomagnetic reversal]], the periodic reversal of the Earth's magnetic field (effectively switching the north and south magnetic poles).
== Speculative history == In popular literature, many conjectures have been suggested involving very rapid polar shift. A slow shift in the poles would display the most minor alterations and no destruction. A more dramatic view assumes more rapid changes, with dramatic alterations of geography and localized areas of destruction due to earthquakes and tsunamis.
=== Early proponents ===
An early mention of a shifting of the Earth's axis can be found in an 1872 article entitled "Chronologie historique des Mexicains"<ref>{{citation | title=Chronologie historique des Mexicains | pages=77–85 | journal=L'ethnographie | publisher=Société d'Ethnographie | volume=7 | location=Paris, France | year=1871 | language=French | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BvwpAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA77#v=onepage&q=&f=false | accessdate=2009-11-08 }}</ref> by [[Charles Étienne Brasseur de Bourbourg]], a specialist in [[Mesoamerican codices]] who interpreted ancient Mexican myths as evidence for four periods of global cataclysms that had begun around 10,500 BCE. In 1889, [[The Purchase of the North Pole|Jules Verne]] imagined the possible consequences of artificial pole shift. In 1948, [[Hugh Auchincloss Brown]], an electrical engineer, advanced a hypothesis of catastrophic pole shift. Brown also argued that accumulation of ice at the poles caused recurring tipping of the axis, identifying cycles of approximately seven millennia.<ref>{{cite book | author=Brown, Hugh Auchincloss | year=1967 | title=Cataclysms of the Earth | publisher=Twayne Publishers }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title=Science: Can the Earth Capsize? | date=September 13, 1948 | work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] | url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,888482,00.html | accessdate=2009-11-08 }}</ref>
In his controversial 1950 work ''[[Worlds in Collision]]'', [[Immanuel Velikovsky]] postulated that the planet [[Venus]] emerged from [[Jupiter]] as a [[comet]]. During two proposed near approaches in about 1,450 BCE, he suggested that the direction of the Earth's rotation was changed radically, then reverted to its original direction on the next pass. This disruption supposedly caused earthquakes, [[tsunamis]], and the parting of the [[Red Sea]]. Further, he said near misses by [[Mars]] between 776 and 687 BCE also caused the Earth's axis to change back and forth by ten degrees. Velikovsky cited historical records in support of his work, although his studies were generally ridiculed by the scientific community.<ref>{{cite book | first=Robert E. | last=Alexander | year=2005 | editor=Robert F. Morgan | title=The Velikovsky Affair: Case History of Iatrogenic Behavior in Physical Science | booktitle=The Iatrogenics handbook: a critical look at research and practice in the helping professions | publisher=Morgan Foundation Publishers | pages=21–24 | isbn=1-885679-11-4 }}</ref>
[[Charles Hapgood]] is now perhaps the best remembered early proponent. In his books ''The Earth's Shifting Crust'' (1958) (which includes a foreword by [[Albert Einstein]])<ref name="Hapgood1958">{{cite book|author=Charles H. Hapgood|title=Earth's Shifting Crust: A Key to Some Basic Problems of Earth Science, introduction by Einstein|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hIwKAQAAIAAJ|year=1958|publisher=Pantheon Books|oclc=150491536|doi=|bibcode=|id=|quote=|laysummary=|laydate=|archiveurl=https://archive.org/stream/eathsshiftingcru033562mbp#page/n5/mode/2up|archivedate=2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author1=Martinez-Frias, Jesus |author2=Hochberg, David |author3=Rull, Fernando | title=Contributions of Albert Einstein to Earth Sciences: A review in Commemoration of the World Year of Physics | date=December 13, 2005 | doi=10.1007/s00114-005-0076-8 | journal=[[Naturwissenschaften]] | volume=93 | issue=2 | pages=66–71 | pmid=16453104 | arxiv=physics/0512114 |bibcode = 2006NW.....93...66M }}</ref> and ''Path of the Pole'' (1970), Hapgood speculated that accumulated polar ice mass destabilizes the Earth's rotation, causing crustal displacement but not disturbing the Earth's axial orientation. Hapgood argued that shifts (of no more than 40 degrees) occurred about every 5,000 years, interrupting 20,000- to 30,000-year periods of polar stability. He cited recent North Pole locations in [[Hudson Bay]] (60°N, 73°W), the Atlantic Ocean between [[Iceland]] and [[Norway]] (72°N, 10°E) and the [[Yukon]] (63°N, 135°W).<ref>Olsen, Brad. 'Modern Esoteric: Beyond Our Senses', San Francisco, CCC Publishing, 2014). {{ISBN|1888729503}}.</ref> However, in his subsequent work ''The Path of the Pole'', Hapgood conceded Einstein's point that the weight of the polar ice is insufficient to cause polar shift. Instead, Hapgood argued that causative forces must be located below the surface.<ref>{{cite book | first=Trevor | last=Palmer | year=2003 | title=Perilous planet earth: catastrophes and catastrophism through the ages | publisher=Cambridge University Press | pages=113–114 | isbn=0-521-81928-8 }}</ref> Hapgood encouraged Canadian librarian [[Rand Flem-Ath]] to pursue scientific evidence backing Hapgood's claims. Flem-Ath published the results of this work in 1995 in ''When the Sky Fell'' co-written with his wife Rose.<ref>Flem-Ath, Rand, Flem-Ath, Rose. ''When The Sky Fell: In Search of Atlantis'' (introduction by [[Colin Wilson]], London: Weidenfeld & Nicolson, 1995). {{ISBN|0-297-81628-4}}</ref>
In 1974 [[Flavio Barbiero]], an engineer and explorer, theorized that shifting of the Earth's axis took place 11,000 years ago and caused what was subsequently recorded in [[myth]] as the destruction of [[Atlantis]] and [[Mu (lost continent)|Mu]]. He suggested that shifting was probably caused by the impact of a comet on the Earth's surface and that the current position of Atlantis has to be sought under the [[Antarctic ice sheet]].<ref>{{cite book | first=Flavio | last=Barbiero | title=Una Civiltà Sotto Ghiaccio | publisher=Casa Editrice Nord, Realtà scientifiche. | isbn=88-429-1168-2 }}</ref>
=== Recent conjectures === {{Fringe theories|section|date=April 2017}} {{Primary sources|section|date=April 2017}} Several authors have offered [[Pseudoscience|pseudoscientific]] arguments for the hypothesis, including journalist and New Age enthusiast [[Ruth Shick Montgomery]],<ref>''Threshold to Tomorrow'', (1984) {{ISBN|978-0-449-20182-4}} {{ISBN|0449201821}}; ''Strangers Among Us'', (1979); ''Aliens Among Us'', (1985) and ''The World to Come: The Guides' Long-Awaited Predictions for the Dawning Age'', (1999).</ref> Richard W. Noone,<ref>{{cite book | author=Noone, Richard W. | title=5/5/2000, ICE: The Ultimate Disaster | location=New York City| date=May 20, 1997 | publisher=Three Rivers Press| isbn=0-609-80067-1 }} Preface, Table of Contents, Appendices.</ref> retired civil engineer James G. Bowles,<ref>{{cite journal | first=James | last=Bowles | title=Hapgood Revisited | journal=Atlantis Rising | issue=18 | year=1999 | url=http://www.atlantisrising.com/backissues/issue18/18hapgood.html | accessdate=2009-11-09 | deadurl=bot: unknown | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120307014441/http://www.atlantisrising.com/backissues/issue18/18hapgood.html | archivedate=2012-03-07 | df= }}</ref> and "William Hutton," reportedly the pseudonym of geologist Wyman Harrison.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.huttoncommentaries.com/aboutus.php|title=About The Hutton Commentaries|last=|first=|date=|website=Hutton Commentaries|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=August 7, 2018}}</ref> Skeptics counter that these works combine speculation, the work of psychics, and modern folklore, while largely ignoring the mainstream scientific view that only the Earth's magnetic poles shift, with little to no observable physical effect.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.skeptic.com/eskeptic/13-02-13/|title=Magnetic Myths|last=|first=|date=|website=Skeptic|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=August 7, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/science/earth-magnetic-field-flip-poles-why-not-facts-weak-a8329921.html|title=Earth's magnetic field is not about to reverse and trigger global catastrophe|last=|first=|date=|work=Independent|access-date=August 7, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.yalescientific.org/2012/05/will-a-magnetic-pole-shift-mean-the-end-of-the-world/|title=Will a Magnetic Pole Shift Mean the End of the World?|last=Smit|first=Josephine|date=May 9, 2012|website=Yale Scientific|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=August 7, 2018}}</ref>
== Scientific research == {{Main article|True polar wander}}
While there are reputable studies showing that [[true polar wander]] has occurred at various times in the past, the rates are much smaller (1° per million years or slower) than predicted by the pole shift hypothesis (up to 1° per thousand years).<ref name=jgr107_b11>{{cite journal |author1=Besse, Jean |author2=Courtillot, Vincent |date=November 2002 | title=Apparent and true polar wander and the geometry of the geomagnetic field over the last 200 Myr | journal=Journal of Geophysical Research: Solid Earth | volume=107 | issue=B11 | page=EPM 6–1 | bibcode=2002JGRB..107.2300B | doi=10.1029/2000JB000050 }}</ref><ref name="jgr90">{{cite journal | author=Andrews, J. A. | title=True polar wander - An analysis of cenozoic and mesozoic paleomagnetic poles | volume=90 | issue=B9 | date=August 10, 1985 | pages=7737–7750 | journal=[[Journal of Geophysical Research]] | bibcode=1985JGR....90.7737A | doi=10.1029/JB090iB09p07737 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author=Hoffman, P. | year=1999 | title=The break-up of Rodinia, birth of Gondwana, true polar wander and the snowball Earth | journal=Journal of African Earth Sciences | volume=28 | issue=1 | pages=17–33 | bibcode=1999JAfES..28...17H | doi=10.1016/S0899-5362(99)00018-4 }}</ref> Analysis of the evidence does not lend credence to Hapgood's hypothesized rapid displacement of layers of the Earth.<ref>{{cite journal | first=Michael | last=Brass | date=July–August 2002 | title=Tracing Graham Hancock's Shifting Cataclysm | journal=[[Skeptical Inquirer]] | volume= 26.4 | url=http://www.csicop.org/si/show/tracing_graham_hancockrsquos_shifting_cataclysm | accessdate=2010-04-19 }}</ref> Data indicates that the geographical poles have not deviated by more than about 5° over the last 130 million years, contradicting the hypothesis of a cataclysmic polar wander event.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Tarduno, John A. |author2=Smirnova, Alexei V. | title=Stability of the Earth with respect to the spin axis for the last 130 million years | journal=[[Earth and Planetary Science Letters]] | volume=184 | issue=2 | date=January 15, 2001 | pages=549–553 | doi=10.1016/S0012-821X(00)00348-4 | bibcode=2001E&PSL.184..549T}}</ref> More rapid past possible occurrences of true polar wander have been measured: from 790 to 810 million years ago, true polar wander of approximately 55° may have occurred twice.<ref name="gsab118"/>
